Public Health Labs:   Currently, in order to be tested for COVID-19 by the Albanian public health authority one must have symptoms and a recommendation from the public health authority’s family doctor.  However, private testing labs will perform a test for a fee, and no symptoms or a doctor’s recommendation is required.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210130213634/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/    We have opened 51 rapid testing points in the community throughout the country. And it is one of the successes of our strategy, as what is happening is that there are no more delays in performing the test. It is performed through online booking with the family doctor.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210130214223/https://shendetesia.gov.al/mbi-55-mije-teste-te-shpejta-manastirliu-ne-piken-e-qytetit-studentit-jemi-ne-mes-te-betejes-vaksina-nepermjet-covax-ne-shkurt/

Before you travel, get tested with a viral test 1–3 days before your trip. After you travel, get tested 3–5 days after travel AND stay home to self-quarantine for 7 days after travel. If you don't get tested, it's safest to stay home to self-quarantine for 10 days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210122004810/https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/covid-4/coronavirus-andorra

After you travel, get tested 3–5 days after travel AND stay home to self-quarantine for 7 days after travel. If you don't get tested, it's safest to stay home to self-quarantine for 10 days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210222022233/https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/covid-4/coronavirus-andorra
No policy change.

If you are self-employed and have had to suspend your activity, you can access a monthly minimum wage benefit.  120 million euros to guarantee the wages of people who have been affected by Covid-19. It is guaranteed to collect the minimum wage (€ 1083.33).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222030344/https://www.andorra-advisors.com/en/blog/covid19-andorra/
No policy change.

If your monthly mortgage payment is equal to or greater than 30% of the income of the family unit, it is canceled.  Suspension of debts, taxes, fees and penalties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222030344/https://www.andorra-advisors.com/en/blog/covid19-andorra/

Andorra is implementing its vaccination campaign using the Pfizer vaccine. The vaccines have been administered to healthcare and social healthcare workers from various fields as well as the residents of the social healthcare homes which have not been recently affected by the virus. The Government has also initiated a campaign to raise awareness and provide information about the vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209112704/https://www.govern.ad/covid19_newsletter/en/
Comprehensive coronavirus portal like the below and public information campaigns  https://visitandorra.com/en/covid-19-in-andorra/  https://www.govern.ad/covid19/en/#situacio

This strategy has been further strengthened using antigen testing. As part of this initiative, the Government has provided three home test kits for every Andorran resident over the age of 6. People are advised to conduct a test, which is done through a nasal swab, before any social gathering.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209112704/https://www.govern.ad/covid19_newsletter/en/

Andorra is continuing periodic screening to contain the spread of the SARS-CoV-2 virus. This strategy has been further strengthened using antigen testing, which can be requested at Andorran pharmacies. People are advised to have this type of test, which is done through a nasal swab, before any kind of meeting or social gathering.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222015447/https://www.govern.ad/covid19_newsletter/en/
No policy change.

Increased detection capacity and rapid control of outbreaks thanks to a large team of contact tracers allows the country to reinforce its strategy against COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201129140822/https://www.govern.ad/covid19/en/

If you are passing through an urban area and/or an outdoor area used by the public:  We recommend maintaining a distance of 4 metres from the person in front and always walking on the right-hand side. It is mandatory wearing a face mask.    If you are in an enclosed area used by the public:   You must maintain a distance of 1.5 metres in enclosed areas; the use of the face mask is mandatory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209111506/https://visitandorra.com/en/covid-19-in-andorra/faq-what-safety-measures-are-being-applied-in-andorra/

In Andorra, everyone over the age of eight must wear a mask and follow the restrictions in place to prevent infection.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222015447/https://www.govern.ad/covid19_newsletter/en/

Schools are nationally closed. While reopening date had been pushed from Jan 18 to Jan 25, it was later pushed again to Feb 8 or Feb 15 dependent.     Exemption possible for special schools - "However, face-to-face teaching is possible for individual groups, classes or the entire school." No evidence of this being used on a widespread level, so coding remains at 3G.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210122141315/https://www.bmbwf.gv.at/Themen/schule/beratung/corona/schulbetrieb20210118.html  https://archive.is/t1nZy

"After the semester break, schools in Lower Austria and Vienna will start on February 8, 2021, in all other federal states from February 15, 2021."     Elementary schools face-to-face. Middle schools and upper schools on shift system.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210222173115/https://www.bmbwf.gv.at/Themen/schule/beratung/corona/schulbetrieb20210118.html    ***Recoded to 3T to reflect that schools in certain states do not resume until after the break on Feb 15.

***Recoded from 2G to 1G as it appears all levels of school - including universities - are able to open under restriction/with their own protocols based on national policy.    Source on universities: https://archive.is/dFdwi    See previous coding notes:     *Schools in middle schools, the AHS lower level and in polytechnic schools*  - Shift work for all students  - The classes are divided into two groups: The students in group A attend school on Monday and Tuesday. Group B students have face-to-face classes on Wednesday and Thursday. On Friday, both groups will be taught distance learning. In the following week, group B comes to school on Monday / Tuesday, group A on Wednesday / Thursday. Friday stays in distance learning. So the change continues.  - Pupils who do not want to be tested receive work assignments for work at home from the teachers in their school.     *Schools in AHS upper levels, vocational middle and higher schools and vocational schools*  - Schools conduct face-to-face classes on a daily basis.  - The lessons should be organized in two-day alternating shifts (group / class A on Monday and Tuesday, group / class B on Wednesday and Thursday). Friday can be used individually for lessons in small groups. More than 50% of the upper secondary school students may never be at the school location at the same time.    Participation in the “entry” self-tests is a prerequisite for attending school. This applies to all types of schools.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210225203418/https://www.bmbwf.gv.at/Themen/schule/beratung/corona/schulbetrieb20210118.html    Primary schools resume regular operations. For secondary levels I and II, face-to-face lessons apply in 2-day shifts. Universities will remain distance learning until further notice. Kindergartens resume normal operations.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222173307/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222173115/https://www.bmbwf.gv.at/Themen/schule/beratung/corona/schulbetrieb20210118.html
Lockdown in place until eased Feb 8    http://web.archive.org/web/20210214171830/https://www.politico.eu/article/austria-eases-lockdown-annoys-bavaria/

***Recoded from 1G to 2G to reflect continued closure of some sectors, "All other culture and leisure facilities such as theatres, cinemas, gyms, pools, and amusement parks are closed" as of Feb. 11 [https://www.austria.info/en/service-and-facts/coronavirus-information - not archivable]     The 4th COVID-19 Protective Measures Ordinance comes into force on February 8th , 2021 and is valid up to and including February 17th, 2021     "Where possible, they should switch to home office.  Distance obligation of at least 2 meters  In closed rooms: close-fitting mouth and nose protection  Further suitable protective measures are possible (e.g. partition walls).  In the case of close contact (e.g. with customers) weekly tests and MNS or FFP2 mask (see above)"    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210212133021/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

Recommendation for working at home where possible.  Some sectors still closed - such as those listed in the leisure and cultural facilities provision in the 4th COVID-19 Protective Measures.    "Leisure facilities are companies and facilities that serve entertainment, amusement or recreation. Leisure facilities that are prohibited from entering in accordance with Paragraph 1 are in particular:  1.Showmen, leisure and amusement parks,  2.Baths and facilities in accordance with Section 1 Paragraph 1 Z 1 to 7 of the Bath Hygiene Act (BHygG), Federal Law Gazette No. 254/1976 ; With regard to baths according to § 1 Para. 1 Z 6 BHygG (baths on surface waters), the prohibition according to Paragraph 1 does not apply if there is no bathing activity in these baths,  3. Dance schools,  4. Betting offices, slot machines, arcades and casinos,  5. Show mines,  6. Facilities for the practice of prostitution,  7. Indoor playgrounds,  8. Paintball systems and  9. Museum railways, but not animal parks, zoos and botanical gardens.    "Cultural institutions are institutions that serve the purpose of cultural development and participation in cultural life. Cultural institutions, which entry is prohibited according to Paragraph 1, are in particular:  1. Theatre,  2. Concert halls and arenas,  3. Cinemas,  4. Vaudeville and  5. Cabarets,  but not museums, art halls, cultural exhibition houses, libraries, libraries and archives."    Source:  https://archive.vn/kAfuY#selection-7197.5-7164.6

Recommendation to work from home where possible.  A number of sectors still closed.    "When entering workplaces, it must be ensured that the professional activity should preferably take place outside the workplace, as far as this is possible and the employer and employee reach an agreement on the performance of work outside the workplace."    Leisure facilities are companies and facilities that serve entertainment, amusement or recreation. Leisure facilities that are prohibited from entering in accordance with Paragraph 1 are in particular  1. Showmen, leisure and amusement parks,  2. Pools and facilities in accordance with Section 1, Paragraph 1, Items 1 to 7 of the Swimming Pool Hygiene Act (BHygG), Federal Law Gazette No. 254/1976; With regard to baths according to § 1 Para. 1 Z 6 BHygG (baths on surface water), the prohibition according to Paragraph 1 does not apply if there is no bathing activity in these pools,  3. Dance schools,  4. Betting offices, slot machines, arcades and casinos,  5. Show mines,  6. Facilities for the practice of prostitution,  7. Indoor playgrounds,  8. Paintball systems and  9. Museum railways, but not animal parks, zoos and botanical gardens.    (3) Cultural institutions are institutions that serve the purpose of cultural development and participation in cultural life. Cultural institutions, which entry is prohibited according to Paragraph 1, are in particular:  1. Theatre,  2. Concert halls and arenas,  3. Cinemas,  4.  Vaudeville and  5. Cabarets, but not museums, art halls, cultural exhibition houses, libraries, libraries and archives.    https://archive.vn/YVWJ5#selection-5773.3-6183.90

Events are still prohibited (e.g. birthday parties, wedding celebrations, cultural events, sporting events).    This does not apply to rehearsals and artistic performances without an audience that take place for professional purposes, as well as professional sports.     Professional meetings that cannot be postponed and meetings for absolutely necessary professional training and further education purposes are possible.     Funerals can take place with a maximum of 50 people.     Demonstrations are allowed.    The minimum distance and the FFP2 obligation must be observed at all events.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210212203745/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/      "Events such as concerts, plays etc. are cancelled." From statute:   "§ 13. (1) Events are prohibited.  (2) Events are in particular planned meetings and activities for entertainment, amusement, physical and mental training and edification. In any case, this includes cultural events, sporting events, wedding celebrations, birthday parties, anniversary celebrations, film screenings, trips with coaches or excursion boats for tourism purposes, congresses, specialist and public fairs and occasional markets."    From legislation summary:  - Events are still prohibited (e.g. birthday parties, wedding celebrations, cultural events, sporting events).  - This does not apply to rehearsals and artistic performances without an audience that take place for professional purposes, as well as professional sports. Professional meetings that cannot be postponed and meetings for absolutely necessary professional training and further education purposes are possible. Funerals can take place with a maximum of 50 people. Demonstrations are allowed.  - The minimum distance and the FFP2 obligation must be observed at all events.    Source: https://archive.vn/kAfuY

"Events are still prohibited (e.g. birthday parties, wedding celebrations, cultural events, sporting events). Evidence of adjusted timetables - and occupation restrictions for certain types of transport.    Cable cars, gondolas & climbing aids: With closed and coverable vehicles, only 50% of the transport capacity may be used, ie only half as many people may be transported. In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn. Operators have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.    In motor vehicles (private car, taxi, Uber) a maximum of two people per row of seats may be carried (exception: shared household). In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222173307/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/

** From 25 January medical-grade FPP2 masks are mandated in shops and on public transport. **    Wearing an FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve (or an equivalent or higher-quality mask) is mandatory for the following areas:     Public transportation  Carpooling, taxis and taxi-like operations as well as at stops, stations and departure halls (also outdoors)  Cable cars and cog railways  Customer areas of commercial establishments as well as of non-body-related service companies (body-related services remain prohibited)  Connecting structures of shopping centers  Markets (indoor and outdoor)  Party traffic by administrative authorities and administrative courts  Gastronomy - if open ( e.g.  when picking up food and in company canteens)  Accommodation establishments - if open (in generally accessible areas such as the lobby or at the reception, does not apply in the room; entry is still only possible for exceptional reasons such as urgent professional purposes)    https://archive.vn/zk0aB  https://archive.vn/TAMfL

In public, closed rooms, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) without an exhalation valve must also be worn.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222173307/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/

In public, closed rooms, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) without an exhalation valve must also be worn. This concerns among other things:    	• Public transport (and the associated underground stations, platforms, stops, train stations and airports),  	• Carpooling,  	• Cable cars and cog railways,  	• Customer areas of commercial establishments as well as of service establishments,  	• Party traffic by administrative authorities and administrative courts,  	• Gastronomy - if open (e.g. when collecting food and in company canteens),  	• Accommodation establishments - if open (in generally accessible areas such as the lobby or at the reception, does not apply in the room); Entry only for exceptional reasons such as for urgent professional purposes,  	• currently permitted events (e.g. funerals),  	• currently open cultural institutions (e.g. museums, art halls, libraries).    The FFP2 mask requirement also applies to people who have recovered from COVID-19 and vaccinated against COVID-19.    NB Exceptions do apply.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222173307/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/

A,B,C: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca    The Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection has a display powered by data from the electronic vaccination system. That system has not yet been completely rolled out. Vaccinations are administered at state level, so exact progress within target groups is difficult to pin point.      However, the statistic being featured on that display at https://archive.vn/FVaTs is that "On average every 5.1 seconds a vaccination dose is administered, currently to persons over the age of 80, residents and staff in care homes and health facilities."      If a reasonable assumption is made that at least some residents in health facilities are likely to be classed as vulnerable, that gives three groups in line with Austria's vaccination schedule, see https://web.archive.org/web/20210222210514/https://www.salzburg.gv.at/gesundheit_/PublishingImages/CORONA/210212_COVID-19-Impfplan.png    The schedule lists those over 80, staff in and residents of old people's and nursing homes and category 1 health staff, along with category 2 health workers, people with disabilities and their carers, plus high-risk patients scheduled for vaccination from mid-February.    Sources: https://archive.vn/FVaTs     https://web.archive.org/web/20210222210514/https://www.salzburg.gv.at/gesundheit_/PublishingImages/CORONA/210212_COVID-19-Impfplan.png

"On average every 5.4 seconds a vaccination dose is administered, currently to persons over the age of 80, residents and staff in care homes and health facilities."    [Hypothesis that at least some patients in health facilities will be clinically vulnerable.]    Source: https://archive.vn/zVTqb

Has the Government of Azerbaijan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes. The Government of Azerbaijan approved the Chinese Sinovac vaccine CoronaVac. Vaccines will be available for tiered groups beginning January 18, 2021.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/

Groups: A.    *No Changes found. The first phase of vaccination programme continues (starting from 18 January 2021), the second phase began on 8 February 2021).  __________________________________________________________________  Quote from linked article 1:  "Azerbaijan has begun the second step of its COVID-19 vaccination program as it undertakes a mass inoculation of its health care workers and older citizens.    The vaccination program kicked off on January 18, making Azerbaijan the first country in the Caucasus or Central Asia to do so. Azerbaijan is relying on China’s CoronaVac vaccine, and as of February 6 had given first doses to 65,000 people, the vast majority of them medical workers, the cabinet of ministers reported.    The second step started on February 8, targeting residents over 65. Eligible Azerbaijanis can either register online or call their local polyclinic to get an appointment. By all accounts, the process has gone smoothly so far."    Web archived link 1:  http://archive.today/2021.02.22-180851/https://eurasianet.org/azerbaijan-starts-mass-covid-19-vaccinations  _____________________________________________________________________________    65,000 doses administered so far (as of 22 feb 2021)    Web archived link 2:  http://archive.today/2021.02.22-180632/https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/region/azerbaijan    ______________________________________________________________________________    Quote from linked article 3:  "Azerbaijan’s vaccination program against Covid-19 that began Monday" (referring to 18th January)    Web archived link 3:  http://archive.today/2021.02.22-181208/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-20/azerbaijan-sees-economy-bouncing-back-after-covid-19-slump-war  _______________________________________________________________________________    Quote from linked articel 4:  "BAKU, Jan. 18 (Xinhua) -- Azerbaijan's senior health officials on Monday took their first inoculations of a vaccine made by Chinese biopharmaceutical company Sinovac Biotech, marking the beginning of mass vaccination against COVID-19 in the country, according to state-run news agency AZERTAC.    Azerbaijani Health Minister Ogtay Shiraliyev and his deputies, as well as other health officials, were among the first to be vaccinated by what Shahmar Movsumov, an assistant to the president of Azerbaijan, earlier described as "the most safe and effective vaccine" procured by Azerbaijan.    Specialists decided that "the best vaccine for Azerbaijan is the vaccine of the Sinovac company" as it has passed clinical tests in many countries, said Shiraliyev, when addressing the local media after his inoculation in Baku.    The first stage of mass vaccination starting on Jan. 18 will cover health and technical workers at the country's medical institutions, law enforcement staff and servicemen, while people aged over 65 will be vaccinated starting from Feb. 1, according to health authorities."    Web archived link 4:  http://archive.today/2021.02.22-182156/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2021-01/18/c_139677882.htm  ____________________________________________________________________________

Attended classes (including internships, internships, outsourced classes, exams, dual system of education, etc.) in schools and personal development support centers are suspended.    From 04.02.2021 to 17.03.2021 an exception is allowed with regard to the present classes for students from fifth to twelfth grade in compliance with the following schedule:    4.02.2021 to 17.02.2021 - students from 7th, 8th and 12th grade are trained in person    18.02.2021 to 2.03.2021 - students from 5th, 10th and 11th grade are trained in person    04.03.2021 to 17.03.2021 - students from 6th, 9th and 12th grade are trained in person    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209041048/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of 9 February, attended classes (including internships, internships, outsourced classes, exams, dual system of education, etc.) in schools and personal development support centers are suspended.     An exception is allowed for students from first to fourth grade and the individual attendance visits to the centers for support of personal development.     Other exceptions are allowed for equivalence exams for student transfer, examinations for determining the annual grade for a student in an independent form of education, examinations for determining the annual grade for a part-time student, state examinations for acquiring a degree of professional qualification in theory and practice of the profession, regional and municipal rounds of Olympiads and competitions, when they cannot be held remotely in an electronic environment.    Visits to kindergartens and nurseries have resumed.     The present learning process in the higher schools is terminated, with the exception of conducting practical trainings and practical exams for students, postgraduates and doctoral students, semester exams which include a practical part and cannot be conducted in an electronic environment, state exams, and diploma theses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209041048/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

The ban does not apply to Bulgarian citizens, citizens of Member States of the European Union (EU), Schengen Parties (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and their family members (including persons in actual residence with them); citizens of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, the Union of Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, the Republic of Rwanda, the Republic of Korea, the Kingdom of Thailand, the Republic of Tunisia, the Oriental Republic of Uruguay, the United Arab Emirates, Ukraine, the Republic of Northern Macedonia The Republic of Albania, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, the Republic of Moldova, Israel, the State of Kuwait, the Republic of Belarus and the Republic of Turkey; persons with permanent status, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and the members of their families; persons holding a Bulgarian long-stay visa type "D", as well as persons holding a residence permit in a Member State of the European Union or a Schengen country (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the City State Vatican) and members of their families.    All persons who are allowed to enter the country are admitted to the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria upon submission of a document showing a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction test conducted up to 72 hours before entry to prove COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209041048/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

There are entry restrictions (except nationals of European Union and the Schengen Agreement States) extended to 30th of April 2021. At airports and other ports of entry are health screening procedures in place. All persons exempted from entry restrictions are also allowed to transit the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/EPVve

A negative COVID-19 PCR test is required for entry in Bulgaria. There are in place health screening procedures at airports and other ports of entry. All persons exempted from entry restrictions are also allowed to transit the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria.  Link: https://archive.fo/w5PHA

As of 9 February, the acceptance of applications for payment of funds under measure 60/40 continues. The application for the measure will continue under the terms of the adopted amendments to Decree 151 of the Council of Ministers of 2020, providing for extension of the deadline for payment of funds until March 31, 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210209053103/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ikonomicheski

As of 9 February, the loan repayment moratorium remains in effect.    Borrowers are able to negotiate with lenders until 31 March 2021 to delay payments of both interest and the principal for nine months. Those who have already had six months of loan repayment holidays can negotiate three additional months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209054115/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102210418/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/972

As of 9 February, the unified information portal remains the official source of information on measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Bulgaria (https://coronavirus.bg). The portal provides statistics, news, press briefings, video materials, information about vaccines, and answers to frequently asked questions.     An official chatbot of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Bulgaria is available, which provides real-time official information and news about COVID-19 through Viber.     The ViruSafe mobile app is available, which gives users the ability to track their symptoms and health status daily. This information gives the Ministry of Health a good overview of the spread of the pandemic. Users can also voluntarily share their location to enable institutions to act accordingly, in case of an emergency.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209054901/https://virusafe.info/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206050526/https://coronavirus.bg/

According to the Order ? RD-01-547/30.09.202 of the Minister of Health, all close contacts of a confirmed case of COVID-19 are subject to a 10-day quarantine, as of their last contact with the infected person. Also, the monitoring of the health condition of each contact person is performed by the general practitioner or the respective regional health inspection.  Link: https://archive.fo/keCbe and https://archive.fo/wip/lRzIP

“A, B, C”: The second phase of vaccination campaign started on 18th of January (for teachers and residents of old-age homes). The immunization with BioNTech-Pfize vaccine started on 27th of December, and on14th of January started the vaccination with Moderna vaccine.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/37ign, https://archive.fo/2wcse and https://archive.fo/wip/H6a6l

“A, B, C”: The second phase of vaccination campaign started on 18th of January (for teachers and residents of old-age homes). The immunization with BioNTech-Pfize vaccine started on 27th of December, and on14th of January started the vaccination with Moderna vaccine.  Link: https://archive.fo/2wcse and https://archive.fo/wip/H6a6l and https://archive.fo/1nhZ0

A:    The immunization of the second and third phases of the National Vaccination Plan against COVID-19 will be carried out in parallel. The members of the Central Election Commission, the district and section commissions, with which the third phase of the plan has started, will be offered the Pfizer / BioNTech vaccine. This ensures that the immunization is completed with two doses of the vaccine, so that those involved in the election can be maximally protected from the virus by election day. The overlap of the phases allows Bulgarian journalists, cameramen and photojournalists to be immunized in the third phase of the Plan.     The third phase will continue with employees of Kozloduy Nuclear Power Plant, water supply and sewage companies employed in the transport and communications sectors, and police officers working on the first line.    Vaccination of vulnerable groups remains a top priority for the Ministry of Health. Therefore, the end of the third phase of the National Vaccination Plan will be covered by the beginning of the fourth. In this phase, those covered by immunization will be "Elderly people over 65 years of age and those with concomitant chronic diseases, due to the more severe course of the disease and the higher risk of complications and death, including immunocompromised or persons with secondary immune deficiencies."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209065902/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1292

A:    More than 5,000 teachers and support staff in Sofia have expressed a desire to be immunized against COVID-19. This is a little over 20% of the pedagogical and non-pedagogical staff in the kindergartens and schools in the municipality of Sofia. Vaccination began on February 1, and more than 160 people were immunized in just one day.     The Sofia Regional Health Inspectorate has so far received about 30,000 doses of Pfizer / BioNTech and Moderna vaccines, informed the director of SRHI, Dr. Dancho Penchev. He explained that the first phase of the National Vaccination Plan is coming to an end in the capital, which includes the medical staff of outpatient and inpatient care facilities, medical specialists in health care, dentists, pharmacists, assistant pharmacists and other support staff.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209070608/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1263

All delivered quantities of AstraZeneca vaccine to be used for the first dose, decided today at its regular meeting the Council of the National Vaccination Headquarters. In this way, larger groups of the population will be covered and the immunization process will be accelerated.    The staff will recommend that medical professionals administer the second dose of the vaccine ten weeks after the first, according to the possibilities provided by the summary of product characteristics.    The members of the vaccination headquarters expressed the opinion that the Oxford vaccine can be used for vaccination of all Bulgarian citizens aged 18 and over.    It became clear at the meeting that the delivery of the Pfizer / BioNTech vaccine was postponed due to bad weather conditions, and is expected to arrive in Bulgaria in the middle of the week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209065902/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1292

A:    Vaccines for all those wishing to participate in the election process are provided, Angelov was adamant. The Ministry of Health has sent a letter to the CEC requesting a list of names and contact details of the people to be immunized. The aim is to create an organization that ensures the safe conduct of parliamentary elections.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210211230615/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1297

Bosnia and Herzegovina has still not started vaccination. Since the country is completely dependent on the COVAX system, the first vaccinations are not expected until mid-February. Between 5,000 and 10,000 doses are expected in the first delivery. So far, vaccinations are only available for 20% of the population. Direct purchases of Pfizer, Sputnik V and Sinopharm vaccinations are expected to vaccinate another 20% of the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210131010146/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

No policy changes.    B;C , Moderna & Pfizer    The following people are being given access to vaccinations first:    People age 75 and over  People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age  People who live in a retirement or care home. Staff who are in contact with residents of retirement and care homes also have the option of being vaccinated at the same time.  If you are in the group of people with chronic diseases of the highest risk, the doctor treating you will urgently recommend you to have the vaccination as soon as possible.    After that come:    People aged between 65 and 74  People under 65 and people with chronic diseases who have not yet been vaccinated  Following people at especially high risk (vulnerable people), the vaccination will also be offered to the following target groups in the corresponding order.    Target group 2: Healthcare professionals with patient contact/carers for people at especially high risk  Target group 3: Close contacts (household members or relatives providing care) of people at especially high risk  Target group 4: People in communal facilities with an increased risk of infection and outbreaks (for example homes for the handicapped).  It has become apparent that these priorities are being put into practice differently from canton to canton. In particular there are differences in the vaccination of healthcare professionals. For this reason the Federal Vaccination Commission (EKIF/CFV) and the FOPH have drawn up guidelines specifying which groups of healthcare professionals may possibly be vaccinated at the same time as especially vulnerable people (target group 1). Given that volumes of vaccine are currently limited, the goal is to assure the provision of healthcare in areas that are particularly affected while making sufficient vaccine available for especially vulnerable people at the highest risk.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210205081724/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

As of 08 February 2021, third class of lyceums and technical schools, including the evening  schools and the respective class of the private schools of secondary education shall operate  with physical attendance. The other classes shall operate through online education,    (iii) Private and public nurseries and kindergartens, including pre-primary schools, shall  operate with physical attendance,    (iv) Special schools and the Special Units of public schools shall operate with physical  attendance,    (v) public and private Higher and Tertiary Education Institutions shall operate through online  education    https://web.archive.org/web/20210204164311/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/28012021_DecreeEN.pdf

No change in policy.    Cyprus has implemented an economic support package that is estimated to amount to €899 million (4.5 percent of GDP) in 2020 for the health sector, households and businesses. The package includes: (i) a €100 million support for the health sector to combat the pandemic; (ii) income support for households including leave allowance for parents and those with health issues; (iii) wage subsidy for affected businesses to maintain jobs, grants to small businesses and self-employed, support for the tourism sector, a two-month deferral of VAT payments, and a temporary VAT cut to stimulate tourism/hospitality sector, and (iv) three-month suspension of a scheduled increase in the contribution to the General Healthcare System and interest subsidy for new business and housing loans for four years, which benefit both businesses and households. This package also includes guarantees on or financing of credit facilities up to €1.7 billion through participation in the Pan-European Guarantee Fund, increased state guarantees to expand existing European Investment Bank (EIB)-supported loans to SMEs, and increased government borrowing from EIB to expand existing funding scheme for SMEs. In face of the second wave, Cyprus has extended some of the support measures until March 2021 in a more targeted manner, including support for crisis-affected businesses and extension of unemployment benefits.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210204173927/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

restrictions are being gradually lifted and no signs of additional economic measures/reliefs  https://web.archive.org/web/20210214185009/https://www.financialmirror.com/2021/02/08/covid19-80000-return-to-work-as-cyprus-eases-lockdown-measures/

No change in policy.    Cyprus has implemented an economic support package that is estimated to amount to €899 million (4.5 percent of GDP) in 2020 for the health sector, households and businesses. The package includes: (i) a €100 million support for the health sector to combat the pandemic; (ii) income support for households including leave allowance for parents and those with health issues; (iii) wage subsidy for affected businesses to maintain jobs, grants to small businesses and self-employed, support for the tourism sector, a two-month deferral of VAT payments, and a temporary VAT cut to stimulate tourism/hospitality sector, and (iv) three-month suspension of a scheduled increase in the contribution to the General Healthcare System and interest subsidy for new business and housing loans for four years, which benefit both businesses and households. This package also includes guarantees on or financing of credit facilities up to €1.7 billion through participation in the Pan-European Guarantee Fund, increased state guarantees to expand existing European Investment Bank (EIB)-supported loans to SMEs, and increased government borrowing from EIB to expand existing funding scheme for SMEs. In face of the second wave, Cyprus has extended some of the support measures until March 2021 in a more targeted manner, including support for crisis-affected businesses and extension of unemployment benefits.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210204173927/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Currently on Stage 3 of the vaccination.  The vulnerable groups of the population refer to:  - Chronic pulmonary illness.  - Severe Chronic Renal Deficiency.  - Cardiac failure of any etiology (ischemic or non-etiological) stage according to  NYHA III or IV.  - Cardiovascular disease  - Congenital heart disease following surgical correction with significant residual  damage or uncorrected congenital heart disease with significant residual  damage.  - Active use of biological agents (e.g. TNF inhibitors, interleukin inhibitors) or  other immunosuppressive drugs.  - Patients with hemoglobinopathy.  - Patients with diabetes mellitus.  - Patients with serious obesity.  - Patients with a history of transplantation.  - Patients with immunodeficiencies.  - Patients with quadriplegia – neurological diseases with pulmonary problems.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210221165302/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/12022021_Statement%20by%20the%20Minister%20of%20Health.pdf

As of Friday, persons who live in the districts of Cheb, Sokolov and Trutnov will be banned from leaving these districts and those who do not live there will be barred from entering.   There will only be a few exceptions to this ban, which will be set by the government’s crisis measure, such as travel to work, travel to ensure health care, services and supplies, public transport, necessary travel to visit medical doctors, authorities, relatives, weddings or funerals.  https://archive.vn/LFPi9

People coming from the countries with very high risk will have to undergo a PCR test for coronavirus before they travel to the Czech Republic and go to quarantine after their arrival. If they undergo another test five or more days afterwards and it is negative again, they will be allowed to end their quarantine, but they will still have to wear an at least FFP2 respirator for five more days.  People from orange countries, with a medium risk, will have to undergo an antigen test not more than 48 hours before their arrival. Until now, this was mandatory only for long-term foreign workers but not for cross-border commuters.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206133544/https://www.expats.cz/czech-news/article/czech-republic-changes-covid-testing-rules-for-arrivals-as-of-friday

"In Länder or districts which still cannot bring their incidence below 50 due to their high 7-day incidence, the Länder or districts will maintain or expand further extensive local or regional measures in accordance with the Protection against Infection Act (Infektionsschutzgesetz) in order to rapidly reduce the number of infections." Testing is only required for symptomatic people who fall under certain risk groups, or when recommended by the primary doctor, asymptomatic people in close contact with someone who has tested positive.  "PCR test should be performed  •	if the patient has severe respiratory symptoms such as bronchitis or pneumonia, shortness of breath or fever,  •	if the patient suffers from a disorder of the sense of smell and taste,  •	if the patient has had contact with a confirmed COVID-19 case,  •	if symptoms worsen.  A test can also be performed for symptoms such as a slight cough.  It is tested for mild respiratory symptoms, in particular (but not exclusively):  •	who belongs to a risk group,  •	who works in nursing, a doctor's office or hospital,  •	Anyone who was exposed, i.e. , for example, was with over 10 people in a closed and poorly ventilated room,  •	Anyone who has had contact with a person with unexplained acute illnesses (e.g. fever) and is in a district with an increased 7-day incidence (> 35 / 100,000 inhabitants),  •	who has or will have close contact with many people or with high-risk patients."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210205062130/https://www.rki.de/DE/Content/InfAZ/N/Neuartiges_Coronavirus/Teststrategie/Nat-Teststrat.html
No policy change.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210212110916/https://www.rki.de/DE/Content/InfAZ/N/Neuartiges_Coronavirus/Teststrategie/Nat-Teststrat.html

Germany has managed to reduce the number of new infections per 100,000 inhabitants over a 7 day period to below 80 nationwide. For some Länder, an incidence of less than 50 is already within sight, although it has not yet been reached.  For contact tracing to be more effective, an acceptable infection rate is 50 cases per 100,000 residents in a 7-day period.  Since this is currently not yet achieved, I have still coded it as 1.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210106175200/https://www.dw.com/en/coronavirus-germany-extends-covid-lockdown-until-january-31/a-56134498  http://web.archive.org/web/20210212102635/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1853278/d9e762ee06ca3822ebd3d8bc78953cd0/2021-02-10-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

Citizens are still encouraged to work from home. Durable goods stores, such as DIY stores and interior design shops, must continue to stay closed, as must shopping centres, department stores, shopping arcades and bazaars. The same applies to liberal professions who are not able to maintain the distance required to prevent infections, such as hairdressers, massage therapists, tattooists and driving schools.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206002505/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/national-measures/covid-19-lockdown    Source showing ongoing lockdown and requirement for workplaces other than essential services to be closed - https://archive.is/IoG7y

a ban on on-site consumption of food and drinks at restaurants etc. and the requirement that indoor cultural and sports facilities must stay closed. Further, citizens are still encouraged to work from home. Durable goods stores, such as DIY stores and interior design shops, must continue to stay closed, as must shopping centres, department stores, shopping arcades and bazaars. The same applies to liberal professions who are not able to maintain the distance required to prevent infections, such as hairdressers, massage therapists, tattooists and driving schools.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210220031726/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/national-measures/covid-19-lockdown#

"Stores, such as DIY stores and interior design shops, with a size of no more than 5000 m2 - that are not located in a shopping centre - can reopen as of 1 March 2021 with a stricter requirement to ensure minimum distance between customers. Stores above 5000 m2 can open for a limited number of customers with a pre-booking. Shopping centres, shopping arcades and bazaars must continue to stay closed. The same applies to liberal professions who are not able to maintain the distance required to prevent infections, such as hairdressers, massage therapists, tattooists and driving schools. On the island of Bornholm, liberal professions who are not able to maintain distance can reopen with the requirement to wear face mask and present a negative COVID-19-test no older than 72 hours.    Further measures applicable until the end of 5 April 2021 include, but are not limited to, a ban on on-site consumption of food and drinks at restaurants etc. and the requirement that indoor cultural and sports facilities must stay closed. Further, citizens are still encouraged to work from home."     https://archive.is/8n1YM

The Danish border closure – imposed on March 14 – remains in place for. Only travelers residents who qualify for a travel exception (called a “worthy purpose” by the Danish government) can enter Denmark. Some travel exceptions include having a valid residence permit for Denmark, attending a business meeting, or being the spouse, parent, or child of a Danish citizen or legal resident in Denmark.      To prevent the spreading of the British and South African mutations of COVID-19, the Danish government has imposed a flight ban on transportation of passengers from the entire world who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test.    The flight ban will enter into force 9 January 2021 at 5pm and last until the end of 28 February 2021.    Link:https://web.archive.org/web/20210130124651/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark/persons-resident-in-countries-outside-of-denmark
Denmark extends ban on all flights from UAE until Feb 2  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208195433/https://travelbans.org/europe/denmark/

Persons resident outside of Denmark can only enter Denmark if they qualify with a worthy purpose and proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before entry. Stricter entry requirements apply to permanent residents in the UK and South Africa. Worthy purposes include being a primary caregiver to a child or attending a funeral.     Coded as 4 as between worthy purpose and covid testing, the border is generally closed except for exceptional cases.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210206011018/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark/persons-resident-in-countries-outside-of-denmark

***Note updated to include details on options for compensation; still current to either Feb 28 2021 or March 7 2021 depending on type   Previous aid scheme is extended https://web.archive.org/web/20210206014917/https://virksomhedsguiden.dk/erhvervsfremme/content/temaer/coronavirus_og_din_virksomhed/ydelser/loenkompensation/8a8e7687-ab06-4524-aea6-dea26d6e95da/  There are currently four options for applying for salary compensation.  One option can all companies throughout Denmark apply for the period 9 December 2020 to 7 March 2021, regardless of  whether you have been affected by restrictions or not. You can  only  apply for the other if you have or have been prohibited from staying open and have not had any turnover on the CVR number or parking unit you are applying for in the period 9 December 2020 to 28 February 2021. The third option is targeted at companies that have been banned from being open during the period 6 November 2020 to 28 February 2021, and applies  as a general rule to  nightclubs, discos, venues with standing audiences and exhibition centers. The fourth option is targeted at companies that have been affected by restrictions in North Jutland in the period 6 November to 26 November 2020.

You should be tested if:    -You have symptoms that could be COVID-19  -You are told that you are in close contact with a person who is infected with a new coronavirus  -You are told that you must be tested prior to, for example, hospitalization, treatment or examination  -You are told that you must be tested as part of infection detection in the event of an outbreak, eg in primary schools, in day care institutions, in nursing homes, etc.  -You are told that you are 'another contact', and must be tested as soon as possible, eg via Infection | stop the app   -You go to work    The regions and the government have entered into agreements with private suppliers to conduct free rapid tests for all Danes. A rapid test (also called an antigen test) detects virus proteins in a sample and is taken by a nasal swab. The rapid test is less sensitive than the PCR test and therefore does not provide an equally reliable answer.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130131819/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/emner/test-

We recommend that you take a test if you have symptoms that could be COVID-19 or if you are a close or 'secondary' contact of someone infected with novel coronavirus. There are other situations in which it would be a good idea to get tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206011726/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Symptoms_tested-positive-or-a-close-contact/On-being-tested
Testing Policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20210206011726/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Symptoms_tested-positive-or-a-close-contact/On-being-tested

If you are infected with COVID-19, you are encouraged to contact the Danish Agency for Patient Safety Corona Detection as soon as possible on tel. 32 32 05 11. In any case, Corona Detection tries to contact the infected person within 24 hours after being notified of a positive test result from the Statens Serum Institut (or private test providers), to offer help in locating and contacting the close contacts who may be infected, and thus can also infect others. The infected person is offered help to call and advise the close contacts. It is voluntary if you want help with this task. As an infected person, you can also be responsible for informing close contacts and referring them. The Danish Agency for Patient Safety contacts citizens both by telephone and letter in e-Boks    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130131217/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/smitteopsporing

If you are infected with COVID-19, you are urged to contact the Patient Safety Safety Authority on 11/32 32 05 11 as soon as possible. In any case, Corona detection attempts to contact the infected person within 24 hours of being notified of a positive sample response from the National Serum Institute (or private test providers) to offer assistance in detecting and contacting close contacts who may be infected, and thus may also infect others.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206012053/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/smitteopsporing
See below for contact tracing   https://web.archive.org/web/20210220045408/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Symptoms_tested-positive-or-a-close-contact/Contact-tracking-and-close-contacts

The current restrictions include the mandatory face mask use in indoor public areas.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130120629/https://www.thelocal.dk/20210127/dont-expect-denmark-to-reopen-at-start-of-february-minister    Wearing a face mask is obligatory:  - On public transport etc., including trains, busses, taxis and ferries, and at train stations and bus stops, etc.  - In establishments selling food, drinks or tobacco for consumption on-site.  - In retail shops, including supermarkets, shopping centres, department stores, bazaars and shopping arcades, takeaway restaurants, etc.  - Indoors in premises for cultural, sports and recreational activities, including museums, sports centres, fitness centres, art galleries, music venues, libraries, cultural centres, zoos, cinemas, theatres and clubs as well as job centres, citizen service centres, etc.   - Indoors in churches or other places of worship.  - At institutions of learning – such as preparatory education, upper secondary schools, adult and continuing education programmes, institutions of higher education, universities, folk high schools, night school, schools of music and arts, driving schools offering theory lessons, etc.  In public and private hospitals and clinics, independent therapists, municipal healthcare services, municipal and private nursing care and assisted living facilities, respite care facilities, as well as foster care facilities and institutions for people with mental disorders or special needs in the social care sector.  - While taking your driving test, including assessing the fitness to drive tests, when others are in the car with you.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130121532/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Prevent-infection/Face-masks

Wearing a face mask is obligatory: on public transport; in establishment selling food, drinks, tobacco; in retail shops; indoors in premises for cultural, sports and recreational activities; indoors in places of worship; at institutions of learning; in hospitals; when taking driving tests.  Wearing a mask is recommended: infected/at risk but have to leave home; at higher risk of severe illness from COVID and hard to social distance; visit someone at higher risk; at large gatherings; in situations where close face-to-face contact is unavoidable    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206002056/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Prevent%20infection/Face%20masks

Accordingly, it is not a general requirement to wear face masks or shields at all premises open to the public.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210220050007/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/national-measures/face-mask-or-shield  Persons aged 12 or more must wear face masks or shields at the following locations:    On public transport etc., including trains, busses, taxis and ferries, and at train stations. However, face mask are not mandatory at bus stops.  At establishments selling food, drinks or tobacco for on-site consumption. Please note that restaurants, bars and similar establishments must stay closed.  In wholesale and retail shops, including durable goods shops, grocery shops, shopping centres, department stores, hypermarkets, bazaars, shopping arcades and establishments selling food or drinks not consumed on-site (takeaway) etc. Please note that durable goods shops, shopping centres, department stores, hypermarkets, shopping arcades and establishments selling food or drinks not consumed on-site must stay closed.  At premises for cultural, sports and club activities, including museums, sports centres, fitness centres, art exhibitions, music venues, libraries, cultural centres, zoos, cinemas, theatres and club premises. Please note that such premises must remain closed to the public. At premises at which the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Denmark or other religious communities perform activities.[ANJ1]   At job centres and citizens service centres.  At day-care facilities, elementary schools and after-school care facilities etc.  At institutions of preparatory education, upper secondary schools, Danish language programmes for adult foreigners etc., adult education and continuing training programmes, institutions of higher education, university extension courses, day folk high schools, evening classes, schools of music and arts, driving schools offering theory training, folk high schools etc.  At public and private hospitals and clinics, with independent therapists, in connection with municipal healthcare services, at municipal and private care homes and assisted living housing, at respite care facilities, at a number of foster care facilities and at institutions for people with mental disorders or special needs in the social care sector.  During practical driving tests, guiding driving tests to assess health issues or final driving tests in vehicles together with other passengers.
Still current; face masks required in several public spaces. However, explicitly states that they aren't required in ALL public spaces.     https://archive.is/lMnQ4#

Based on the proposals from the Government’s scientific advisory council and the Health Board, the Government members have decided to harmonise the restrictions established in Estonia due to extensive nationwide spread of the coronavirus.    The new restrictions will take effect in Harju and Ida-Viru County from Monday, 1 February, and in all other counties from Wednesday, 3 February.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131125425/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/government-harmonise-covid-19-restrictions-throughout-estonia

New restrictions to prevent the spread of coronavirus have entered into force across Estonia on Wednesday (February 3). The rules were introduced in Harju and Ida-Viru counties on Monday but now apply across the country.  People can stay at restaurants, bars, cafes, night-clubs, bowling alleys, and elsewhere until 9 p.m. No restrictions will be established for take-away sales at catering establishments.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206132259/https://news.err.ee/1608093460/new-coronavirus-restrictions-enter-into-force-across-estonia

Today, the Government approved Estonia’s positions on the EU Council’s recommendations concerning a coordinated approach to the temporary restriction of non-essential travel in order to prevent the continued spread of COVID-19.    The EU Council’s proposals aim to limit non-essential movement both within the EU and from third countries, due to the spread of COVID-19. These include, for example, testing requirements before travelling and upon arrival, as well as self-isolation requirements.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131125612/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/government-approve-eu-council-recommendations-travel-restrictions-prevent-spread-covid-19

In accordance with the amendment to the order, a close contact of a person diagnosed with COVID-19 does not have to remain in quarantine for 10 days from 2 February if they have recovered from COVID-19 during the last six months and have been declared healthy by a doctor or if they have been vaccinated against COVID-19 during the last six months.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206132620/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/government-provides-exemptions-restrictions-people-who-have-recovered-and-been-vaccinated
No change in policy  https://web.archive.org/web/20201024002729/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-spread-testing-treatment-prevention-masks/personal-protection-equipment--masks-and-similar

Most recent update: "High schools continue in distance education until 28.2. Distance learning will continue in vocational education from 1.2.2021 until 28.2.2021. During the teaching arrangements, students are provided with opportunities to complete parts of the degree and degrees in different learning environments as needed (online teaching, educational institution and workplace)." The regions in Finland have been divided into three phases: baseline, acceleration and spread. These are used to assess the need for recommendations and restrictions, as well as targeting.  In the acceleration and dissemination stage, it is recommended that some education institutions seriously consider switching to distance learning, however, taking into account the needs of the necessary contact teaching. Finnish gov announced updates to the testing strategy.     "The government also drew attention to the importance of making sure the number of sample collection sites and methods is sufficient and the sites easily accessible.    “Mobile or targeted low-threshold testing sites will be set up for regions and population groups where the number of infections is high and where it can be suspected people are not accessing ordinary testing services sufficiently. Rapid tests will utilised increasingly in the testing effort to the extent possible.”    The testing capacity will be directed especially at people with symptoms, although also asymptomatic people should be tested if deemed necessary by health care officials. Infections caused by the new more transmissible variants should be investigated and the chains of infections identified without delay, the government said."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210212214521/https://www.helsinkitimes.fi/finland/finland-news/domestic/18685-finnish-government-updates-coronavirus-testing-strategy.html

The imposition of a national curfew between the hours of 6pm and 8am since January 16 2021 means that most workplaces must close during these hours. Since February 1 2021, non-food businesses larger than 20,000 square meters are closed. Bars, restaurants, cinemas, theaters, sports and leisure facilities, winter sports venues and nightclubs are closed. - https://web.archive.org/web/20210208211635/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

For most of the country, there is no change to existing guidance. https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus     In the Alpes-Maritimes department and in the Dunkirk region, additional measures are being implemented in response to an increase in Covid-19 infection rate. In these areas:     "businesses will have to comply with new measures. In particular, these institutions will need to have a COVID referent responsible for ensuring the proper implementation of the barrier gestures. Controls on the implementation of barrier actions in public-receiving establishments and covered and uncovered markets will also be strengthened.    In addition, the attendance gauge in shops will be lowered. For businesses over 400 sqm, the gauge will be increased from 10 sqm per customer to 15 sqm per customer. Food shops are invited to advance their opening hours in the morning in order to further spread their attendance.    Shops, commercial spaces or commercial units (including distributed by outdoor aisles) of more than 5,000 square metres, with the exception of food shops, pharmacies (similar to shopping centres over 20,000 sqm) will be closed. However, from Monday 6am to Friday 6pm, these businesses will be able to continue to welcome the public only for click-and-collect activities and ensure deliveries. These businesses remain bound by curfew rules."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227042501/https://www.alpes-maritimes.gouv.fr/Actualites/COVID-19-Point-sur-la-situation-dans-les-Alpes-Maritimes/COVID-19-Adoptions-de-mesures-complementaires and https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

***Updated to add coding note: "Limit social contacts as much as possible (6 maximum)"   https://web.archive.org/web/20210212193900/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Government guidelines are to:  - "Limit social contacts as much as possible (maximum 6)".   - "It is not possible to receive guests at home during the curfew. Persons attending this type of invitation will not be able to justify their travel by any of the permitted reasons for travel. They are therefore liable to a fine of 135 euros for a first offence and up to 3750 euros for repeated non-compliance with curfew rules."  - "Throughout the country, theatres, shows and cinemas are closed to the public. On the other hand, professional artists wishing to rehearse or capture can visit these establishments. In addition, all over the country, multi-purpose rooms and party halls are closed. They may remain open to a mission of general interest (welcoming a vulnerable public, blood collection, etc.). Libraries and archives are open to the public, in accordance with strict health protocols."  - "No, private rooms are not allowed to open to host such events. [Marriages, baptisms]"  - "Professional sports competitions can still take place but will have to take place behind closed doors, the reception of the public will be prohibited. Amateur sports competitions are suspended."  - "Throughout the country, gyms, casinos, gaming rooms, fairs and fairs will have to remain closed to the public."  - "Gatherings of more than 6 people on public roads are prohibited with the exception of demonstrations declared to the prefectural authorities, funeral ceremonies or patriotic ceremonies that will have to guarantee compliance with the barrier measures."  - "Attendance at a City Council meeting is not a derogatory reason for individuals to travel during curfew hours. Elected officials, on the other hand, can travel under the title of "professional travel."  The local executive may decide, in order to ensure that the meeting of the deliberative body is held under conditions in accordance with the current health rules, that it should take place without the public being allowed to attend or by setting a maximum number of persons authorized to  attend. The public nature of the meeting is deemed satisfactory when the debates are available live to the public electronically. If so, this decision on the convening of the deliberative body should be referred to."  - "Parks and gardens, as well as beaches, lakes and bodies of water, remain accessible if they are within the 20-kilometre limit around his home. On the other hand, it is not possible to gather there more than 6 people."  - "Places of worship are allowed to open and offices are allowed to be held there in accordance with a health protocol and an organisation allowing two seats to be left free between each person or family entity and to occupy only one row out of two. Civil marriages can take place in accordance with a health protocol and an organization that allows two seats to be left free between each person or family entity and to occupy only one row out of two."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212193900/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212193900/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Telecommuting is required for work whenever possible. "On January 14, 2021, the Prime Minister announced the advancement of the curfew from 8:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. throughout the metropolitan territory from Saturday January 16, 2021 for a minimum duration of 15 days. The objective of the curfew is to limit gatherings during which barrier measures are less well applied and where the virus circulates quickly while limiting the impact on the economy already strained by the epidemic. Outings and trips without a derogatory certificate are therefore prohibited from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. throughout mainland France, under penalty of a fine of € 135 and up to € 3,750 in the event of a repeat offense." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210208211635/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

There are no restrictions on internal movement per se, however curfew restrictions mean that travel must be completed between the specified curfew hours with very limited exceptions.     "With regard to long journeys by car, travel must be justified by one of the reasons for derogatory reasons (for professional reasons, health, to assist vulnerable or insecure people, etc.). For any other reason of travel, it is necessary to arrange to leave after 6am and arrive at your destination before the curfew starts at 8pm. In some departments, the schedule is 6 p.m."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212193900/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    The US Embassy in France reports that "Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No.There are no restrictions for traveling within France." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210208220901/https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From February 26 through March 1, and again from March 5 through March 8th, travel into and within the Alpes-Maritimes region will be restricted. Extracts from the requirements published by the Alpes-Maritimes Department follow:     - Partial containment will be implemented from Friday, February 26 at 6 p.m. to Monday, March 1 at 6 a.m. and Friday, March 5 at 6 p.m. to Monday, March 8 at 6 a.m. During these periods, travel not justified by one of the derogatory reasons will be prohibited. These derogatory reasons, which will be certified, relate to travel related to a professional activity or the purchase of supplies related to the exercise of a professional activity; travel related to the purchase of basic necessities; Travel for medical reasons Travel motivated by compelling family motives; travel related to individual physical activity and the exit of pets for up to one hour and within a 5 km radius around the home.  - The area affected by this measure extends over the coastal area of the Alpes-Maritimes  - As for the conditions of entry into the territory, they will be subject to strengthened controls, at the Franco-Italian border (road and rail lanes) as well as at Nice Côte d'Azur and Cannes-Mandelieu airports with the completion of PCR tests on all passengers of randomly selected flights.  - The internal security forces are fully mobilized to ensure compliance with these measures, as are the state services in charge of the control of trades.    Full details at https://web.archive.org/web/20210227042501/https://www.alpes-maritimes.gouv.fr/Actualites/COVID-19-Point-sur-la-situation-dans-les-Alpes-Maritimes/COVID-19-Adoptions-de-mesures-complementaires

PM Jean Castex announced that from Sunday (Jan 31, 2021), apart from exceptional reasons, "any entry into France and any exit from our territory to or from a country outside the European Union will be prohibited". A number of countries are exempted, as they are not considered at risk , such as Australia, South Korea, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore and Thailand. However, arrivals from inside the EU and several other neighbouring states will have to present a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210202051603/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-55863069

"From Sunday January 31, any entry into France and any exit from our territory to or from a country outside the European Union is prohibited, except for an overriding reason. Entries in France, including for the European Union, are conditional on presentation of a negative PCR test. Travel to overseas territories is authorized only on compelling reasons."  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210208211635/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

"From Sunday 31 January, all entry into France and any exit from our territory to or from a country outside the European Union are prohibited, unless compelling reason is required. Entries to France, including for the European Union, are conditional on the presentation of a negative PCR test. Overseas travel is permitted only on compelling grounds." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210212193900/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    Per the US Embassy in France, "Travelers to France will need to self-isolate for seven days upon arrival and test again at the end of the self-isolation period, even if they tested negative prior to boarding.  Travelers from certain EU countries experiencing a sharp increase in infections may also be subject to unidentified extra border restrictions." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210208220901/https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Agree with previous coding note that "available but not comprehensive. There is a contact tracing app; however can't find evidence of comprehensive contract tracing in practice. Past coding for this indicator seems to either say 'no change in policy' or reference vague government statements. Per the US Embassy in France:    - Cloth face coverings are required on all public transportation and in all public spaces, including in the stations.  - Failing to wear a cloth face covering where required can result in a 135 Euro fine (approximately $165).  - Many French cities now require cloth face coverings in outdoor areas throughout or in designated parts of the city. This includes Paris and its suburbs, where cloth face coverings are required in all outdoor locations. Rules vary by city and can change quickly. Check with the website of each city.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20210208220901/https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A, C:    As of Jan 24, 1,092,958 people received the first dose of Covid-19 vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126170527/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
A,C:    PfizerBiontech and Moderna vaccines are being administered, https://web.archive.org/web/20210128112737/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

A,C:     As of February 5th, over 2 million vaccinations have given in France https://web.archive.org/web/20210207203851/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/actualites/presse/communiques-de-presse/article/vaccin-anti-covid-premiere-livraison-de-doses-du-vaccin-astrazeneca-ce-samedi-6    PfizerBiontech and Moderna are being administered, with the AztraZeneca vaccine available as of February 6th. Following approval by EMA on January 29th 2020, the Haute autorité de santé (HAS) approved the AstraZeneca vaccine for use with two groups: "people under 65, starting with professionals in the health or medico-social sector, whatever their age; and in people aged 50 to 64, prioritizing those with co-morbidities" per https://web.archive.org/web/20210207203851/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/actualites/presse/communiques-de-presse/article/vaccin-anti-covid-premiere-livraison-de-doses-du-vaccin-astrazeneca-ce-samedi-6    France24 reported that first doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine were administered to health workers on Feb 6 2021 at "The Hospices Civils de Lyon, which received 7,700 doses on Friday evening [...] began to vaccinate their nursing staff and liberal doctors on Saturday afternoon at the Édouard-Herriot hospital, according to their press service." https://web.archive.org/web/20210208213549/https://www.france24.com/fr/france/20210206-covid-19-premi%C3%A8res-injections-du-vaccin-d-astrazeneca-en-france    This addition will expand availability to Group B (clinically vulnerable groups), adding this cohort to existing Key Worker and Elderly groups that are eligible for vaccination. Although the first doses of the AstraZeneva vaccine were delivered to France on February 6th, injection of people will begin "As soon as the quantities delivered allow it, it can be administered by town doctors, then, subsequently, in local pharmacies, for people meeting the criteria required by the HAS (people aged 50 to 64, starting with those with comorbidities). The exact date of initiation of vaccination for these people will be communicated very soon, depending on the doses available." so coding remains as 2G, but should move to 3G in the near future.

A,B,C:  PfizerBiontech, Moderna and AztraZeneca vaccines are being administered.   The full list of people eligible for vaccination is available at , and includes:  - people aged over 75 - voluntary residents of elderly care homes and health facilities - people with disabilities or vulnerabilities housed in specialized living facilities or migrant workers homes - health professionals, home helpers working with the elderly or vulnerable people, firefighters aged over 50 or with one or more comorbidities - Clinically vulnerable people with a prescription  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207203851/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/actualites/presse/communiques-de-presse/article/vaccin-anti-covid-premiere-livraison-de-doses-du-vaccin-astrazeneca-ce-samedi-6
