Mainland Portugal:  The Government closed the schools again, due to the exponential increase of cases of covid-19 in the country, and, after a suspension of the teaching activities, the classes will resume at a distance as early as next February 8th.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210206172748/https://tvi24.iol.pt/sociedade/ensino-a-distancia/telescola-estes-sao-os-novos-horarios-para-as-aulas-em-casa    Madeira  Face-to-face classes for students in the 3rd Cycle and Secondary Education are suspended in all schools in the Autonomous Region of Madeira  until February 21. All other levels of education : daycare centers / kindergartens / pre-school / 1st and 2nd cycles / special and professional education maintain their activities in person.  Link:https://web.archive.org/web/20210206170727/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19    Azores: Schools appear open in Sao Miguel. In the municipalities of Ponta Delgada, Lagoa, Nordeste and Povoação, the remaining levels of education will continue to have distance classes. In the municipalities considered to be at high risk for the spread of covid-19, Vila Franca do Campo and Ribeira Grande, all schools, at all levels of education, will remain closed.  Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206172645/https://edu.azores.gov.pt/regressoseguro/

Mainland Portugal:    "The Prime Minister announced a 15-day school break (for all levels), which takes effect on Friday (January 22), which is justified by a "precautionary principle" because of the increase in the number of cases of the most contagious variant of SARS-CoV-2 , which have grown from around 8% prevalence in the past week to around 20% today."     "The Government closed the schools again, due to the exponential increase of cases of covid-19 in the country, and, after a suspension of the teaching activities, the classes will resume at a distance on Monday, February 8th."    Sources:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210130172354/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-01-21-Covid-19.-Governo-decide-fechar-todos-os-niveis-de-ensino-por-15-dias  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206172748/https://tvi24.iol.pt/sociedade/ensino-a-distancia/telescola-estes-sao-os-novos-horarios-para-as-aulas-em-casa    Madeira : "Face-to-face classes for students in middle and high school are suspended in all schools in the Autonomous Region of Madeira  until February 21 .    All other levels of education : day care centers / kindergartens / pre-school / 1st and 2nd cycles / special and professional education maintain their activities in person .    All out-of-school activities, in person, are suspended until February 21st."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213145430/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19

Mainland portugal: Online classes are now in effect for all students in Portugal.  In-person classes continue to be suspended with the exception of schools for children under 12 years old, whose parents work in essential services.  Day centers for the elderly are also closed.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210220114439/https://pt.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Madeira: - Face-to-face classes for students of the 3rd Cycle and Secondary Education are suspended in all schools in the Autonomous Region of Madeira  until March 1 .  - All other levels of education : day care centers / kindergartens / pre-school / 1st and 2nd cycles / special and professional education maintain their activities in person .  - All out-of-school activities, in person, are suspended until March 1.  Link:https://web.archive.org/web/20210220120555/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19    Azores: The students of the Basic and Secondary School of Vila Franca do Campo remained in distance learning for more than a month due to Covid-19 and claim to have had difficulties.  Vila Franca do Campo recorded a high number of active cases in the municipality for several weeks and, therefore, schools remained with distance learning. The return to the face-to-face regime was a decision taken by the Regional Education Secretariat, due to the last risk assessment by the Health Authority. In Ribeira Grande, schools will also resume face-to-face education, with the exception of the village of Rabo de Peixe.  Link: https://archive.vn/X18qQ

"Online classes are now in effect for all students in Portugal.  In-person classes continue to be suspended with the exception of schools for children under 12 years old, whose parents work in essential services."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210223163836/https://pt.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Mainland Portugal : "The State of Emergency was decreed until 30 January, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on 15 January (...) Establishments and services closed to the public: hairdressers / barber shops; gyms; sports facilities, even outdoors; museums, cultural and leisure spaces;    Source: https://archive.vn/japFQ#selection-2317.0-2317.150    Azores : "The regional government has implemented a regional state of alert. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus.  There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high."     From midnight on Saturday, January 30:    Low Risk islands: "Closure of all drinks and similar establishments, with dance spaces"  Medium Risk Islands : "Closure of all restaurants, drinks and similar establishments at *8:00 pm*, with or without a show and with or without terrace service, including spaces for holding events, except for take-away or home delivery purposes (...) Prohibition of the sale of alcoholic beverages after 8:00 pm, unless in restaurant service"  High risk Islands : "Closure of daycare centers and ATL; (...) Closure of gymnasiums and covered swimming pools, with the practice of sports in these spaces being prohibited; Closure of casinos and gambling establishments"    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183029/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8896  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183311/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8888  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183443/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8891    Madeira : "Until February 21, all activities of an industrial, commercial and service nature must, imperatively, close:    - During the days of the week : until 18h.  - Saturdays, Sundays and municipal holidays : until 17h.    Until February 21, all gambling establishments, casinos, bingo or similar, must close:  - Weekends : until 17h.  - During the week : at 6 pm.    Until the 21st of February restaurants are allowed to open:    - During the days of the week (Monday to Friday): until 6pm.  - Weekends : until 17h, and the takeaway service and home deliveries will be closed from that time."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130172656/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19    Note: Since in Madeira AND in low risk islands in the Azores establishments are allowed to be open (despite the restrictions in terms of schedules) the flag (targeted remains unchanged).

Mainland portugal: Shops and other commercial premises, with the exception of supermarkets, grocery and hardware stores, pharmacies and petrol stations, are closed. Stores that remain open have shorter trading hours, as follows:  Weekdays – all shops and supermarkets close at 8pm  Weekends – shops close at 1pm; supermarkets and grocery stores close at 5pm  Restaurants and cafés are closed, except for takeaways and food delivery services. Food that is collected must be eaten at home. The sale of alcohol and other drinks is prohibited.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210206170145/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-    Azores  High risk: Closure of all restaurants, beverages and similar establishments at 3 pm; From 15:00 hours until 22:00 hoursts can only operate with home delivery and take-away service. Closing of all commercial activity at 8:00 pm during the week and at 3:00 pm at the weekend, with the exception of pharmacies, medical clinics and offices, fuel filling stations with sale to the wicket, convenience stores selling essential goods integrated in gas stations, or not, establishments located inside the airports of the Region, in an area located after screening and security control of passengers, who can work after those hours; Closure of gymnasiums and covered swimming pools, with the practice of sports in these spaces being prohibited; Closure of casinos and gambling establishments;  Medium risk:Closure of all restaurants, drinks and similar establishments at 8 pm, except for take-away or home delivery purposes;  Low risk: Closure of all beverage and similar establishments, with dance spaces; Closure, from 10 pm, of all catering establishments, drinks and the like, with or without a show and with or without terrace service, including spaces for holding events, except for take-away or delivery purposes at home; Fuel filling stations can maintain their operation from 22:00 hours until 06:00 hours of the following day, exclusively for the purpose of selling fuel and supplying vehicles to the public    Link:https://web.archive.org/web/20210206171027/https://covid19.azores.gov.pt/    Madeira  Until February 21, all activities of an industrial, commercial and service nature must imperatively close:  - During the days of the week : until 18h.  - Saturdays, Sundays and municipal holidays : until 17h.  Exceptions: Workshop pharmacy; Clinics, medical and veterinary offices, medical services or other health and social support services; Oxygen and medical gas services at home; Fuel filling stations (only for filling vehicles); Bakery sector; Port activity of loading and unloading of goods and their distribution. The commercial establishments located inside the airports of Madeira and Porto Santo, after checking the security of passengers.  Restaurants - only home delivery      Link: Link:https://web.archive.org/web/20210206170727/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19

Mainland Portugal : "The State of Emergency was decreed until 1 March (...)    Establishments and services open to the public  - Essential goods shops, grocery shops, supermarkets and hypermarkets may operate without time restrictions;  - Health services, offices, dentists and pharmacies;  - Restaurants and cafes may only operate on a take-away or home delivery basis;  - Fairs and markets are allowed for food sales only.  Shops must close by 8 pm on weekdays. At the weekend, shops should close at 1 pm, except supermarkets and food shops that may be open to the public until 5 pm.  The time restriction is not applicable to accommodation units, local accommodation, rent-a-car and establishments located inside airports after the passenger security check.  In hotel bars and restaurants, operation is permitted for the purpose of room-service or take-away.    Establishments and services closed to the public  - Hairdressers / barber shops;  - Gyms closed;  - sports facilities, even outdoors;  - Museums, cultural and leisure spaces"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213171414/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    Madeira:     "Until February 21, all activities of an industrial, commercial and service nature must, imperatively, close until 5 pm.    Exceptions include:    - Workshop pharmacies;  - Clinics, medical and veterinary offices, medical services or other health and social support services;  - Oxygen and medical gas services at home;  - Fuel filling stations (only for filling vehicles);  - Bakery sector;  - Port activity of loading and unloading of goods and their distribution;  - The commercial establishments located inside the airports of Madeira and Porto Santo, after checking the security of passengers;  - Tourist developments and local accommodation establishments.    Gambling Establishments : Until February 21, all gambling establishments, casinos, bingo or similar, must close until 5 pm.    Restaurants, Bars and Similar Establishments : Until February 21, they must close until 5 pm.    Between February 15 and 19, 2021, it will be allowed to operate between 5 pm and 10 pm, only for making meals, exclusively for home delivery."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213145430/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19    Azores:     "The Azores will apply, as of 8 pm this Friday and during the Carnival period, traffic restrictions, banning parties and limiting trade and catering hours, to control the spread of Covid-19.    The measures, which will be applied in all municipalities of the archipelago, come into force at 8 pm and extend until 11:59 pm on Tuesday, although they are more restrictive at the weekend.    (...) Between 8:00 pm on Friday and 11:59 pm on Sunday, there is an obligation to close “all non-essential trade, considering as essential trade establishments that provide essential goods or other goods considered essential, or those that provide services first need ”.    During this period, the “restaurants, beverages and similar establishments are also closed, with the exception of take-away and home delivery services”.    On Monday and Tuesday, restaurants, beverages and similar establishments can open until 3:00 pm, after that time, only take-away and home delivery."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213150934/https://observador.pt/2021/02/12/acores-com-restricoes-a-circulacao-e-limitacoes-de-horarios-no-carnaval/

Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus.  There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high."     From midnight on Saturday, January 30:    Low Risk islands: "Suspension of the holding of public events promoted by the regional administration, including public institutes and public companies, extending this recommendation to all public entities, namely local authorities, as well as to private sector entities, urging the non-holding of events open to the public"  Medium Risk Islands : "Suspension of opening to the public at sporting events and competitions"  High risk Islands : "Limitation of gatherings on the public road of a maximum number of four people, unless they are from the same household"    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183029/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8896  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183311/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8888  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183443/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8891

Mainland Portugal : "The State of Emergency was decreed until 30 January, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on 15 January. (...) There will be a general duty of home retreat. It will not be allowed to circulate in public spaces and roads, with the exception of authorized travel on which the following stand out: acquisition of essential goods and services; access to public services; professional activities (if accompanied by a statement); health reasons; assistance to vulnerable people; short walks for physical activity, individually or with members of the same household; pet walk; travelling necessary to enter or leave the mainland, including those necessary to travel to and from the place of accommodation; homecoming within the framework of permitted situations; refuelling at petrol stations as part of permitted journeys."    Source: https://archive.vn/japFQ#selection-2285.0-2285.111    Madeira: "Until February 21, circulation on public roads is prohibited:     - During the days of the week : between 19h and 05h the next day.  - Saturdays, Sundays and local holidays : between 18h and 05h the next day"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130172656/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19      Azores:  "The regional government has implemented a regional state of alert. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus.  There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high."     From Saturday, January 30:    Low and medium risk islands : NO stay at home requirements.  High risk islands: "Prohibition of pedestrian, car, motorized or similar circulation on public roads between 8:00 pm and 5:00 am the following day on weekdays and between 3:00 pm and 5:00 am the day after weekend, except as provided in paragraph 4"    NOTE: In low and middle risk islands in the Azores there are no stay at home requirements which is why the code remains unchanged despite the additional measures announced by the regional government.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183029/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8896  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183311/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8888  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183443/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8891

Mainland Portugal:  Currently in a ‘state of emergency.’ The Portuguese government has put in place a series of measures to control the spread of the virus, including a national lockdown. You are instructed to stay at home, except:  - to buy food and other essential items  - to go to work exceptionally, if your professional activity is not compatible with working from home  - to go to a hospital, health centre or dental clinic  - to go to a veterinary clinic or walk a pet  - to carry out caring or similar duties  - to take short periods of exercise outdoors (individually, not in groups)    Maderia:  Currently in a state of calamity. Measures are in place to limit the spread of the virus. Until further notice, you are obliged to stay at home:  - on weekdays from 7pm to 5am  - on weekends and public holidays from 6pm to 5am    The Azores  Currently in a state of emergency. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus. There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high. Each level has its own restrictions. In the high-risk municipalities of Ribeira Grande and Vila Franca do Campo on the island of São Miguel, you are obliged to stay at home until further notice, as follows:  - On weekdays from 8pm to 5am.  - On weekends from 3pm to 5am    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210206170145/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-

Mainland Portugal:    "The State of Emergency was decreed until 1 March (...) There will be a general duty of home retreat. It will not be allowed to circulate in public spaces and roads, with the exception of authorized travel on which the following stand out:  - acquisition of essential goods and services;  - access to public services;  - professional activities (if accompanied by a statement);  - health reasons;  - assistance to vulnerable people;  - school attendance;  - short walks for physical activity, individually or with members of the same household;  - pet walk;  - travelling necessary to enter or leave the mainland, including those necessary to travel to and from the place of accommodation;  - homecoming within the framework of permitted situations;  - refuelling at petrol stations as part of permitted journeys.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213171414/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    Madeira :     "Until February 21, circulation on public roads is prohibited between 6:00 pm and 5:00 am the following day.    Exceptions:    - Professional travel, as attested by statement;  - Health professionals and other workers from health and social support institutions;  - Civil protection agents, military personnel, inspectors from the Regional Economic Activities Authority (ARAE) and security forces;  - Cult ministers;  - Diplomatic and consular mission staff;  - Displacement for health reasons;  - Emergency reception of victims of domestic violence or trafficking in human beings;  - Assistance to vulnerable persons or persons with disabilities;  - Fulfill parental responsibilities;  - Urgent medical-veterinary assistance;  - Exercise of freedom of the press;  - Homecoming within the scope of admitted travel;  - Travel to the airport to board and disembark passengers;  - Travel by public transport, taxis and TVDE, within the scope of the exceptions allowed here;  - Bakery professionals, for night work;  - Other urgent reasons, provided that it can be shown that they cannot be delayed."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213145430/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19    Azores:     "The Azores will apply, as of 8 pm this Friday (February 12) and during the Carnival period, traffic restrictions, banning parties and limiting trade and catering hours, to control the spread of Covid-19.    The measures, which will be applied in ALL municipalities of the archipelago, come into force at 8 pm and extend until 11:59 pm on Tuesday, although they are more restrictive at the weekend.    (...) In the same period, traffic on public roads between 8:00 pm and 5:00 am will also be prohibited, with the exceptions provided for by law, such as travel for health reasons, to work and to purchase essential goods".    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213150934/https://observador.pt/2021/02/12/acores-com-restricoes-a-circulacao-e-limitacoes-de-horarios-no-carnaval/

"Mainland Portugal is currently in a ‘state of emergency.’ The Portuguese government has put in place a series of measures to control the spread of the virus, including a national lockdown.    You are instructed to stay at home, except: to buy food and other essential items, to go to work exceptionally, if your professional activity is not compatible with working from home, to go to a hospital, health centre or dental clinic, to go to a veterinary clinic or walk a pet  to carry out caring or similar duties, to take short periods of exercise outdoors (individually, not in groups)"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210226224854/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus

Inter-island travel  "You should only travel between islands if your journey is essential. If you have to travel and you are travelling from São Miguel or Terceira to any of the other islands in the archipelago, you will need to have a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before you travel and show the negative result when you board, and complete a passenger questionnaire before you depart."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130165532/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  Movement between municipalities in mainland Portugal during the weekend will be prohibited, between 8pm on Friday, January 29 to 5am on Monday, February 1.  Source: https://archive.vn/japFQ  Note: Since during this weekend restrictions apply to the entire Portuguese territory (mainland + Madeira + Azores) the code was upgraded to 2G.

You should only travel between islands if your journey is essential. If you have to travel and you are travelling from São Miguel or Terceira to any of the other islands in the archipelago, you will need to have a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before you travel and show the negative result when you board, and complete a passenger questionnaire before you depart.    Note: According to the codebook "Some examples that could indicate a 2:  (...) requirement of negative test result" hence the 2T code.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210206170145/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-

Mainland Portugal : "Movement between municipalities at the weekend will be prohibited, between 8pm on friday, February 5, to 5am on Monday, February 8."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210207062815/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    Azores and Madeira Islands:    "You should only travel between islands if your journey is essential. If you have to travel and you are travelling from São Miguel or Terceira to any of the other islands in the archipelago, you will need to have a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before you travel and show the negative result when you board, and complete a passenger questionnaire before you depart."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130165532/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-    "Madeira : "All passengers, whether Portuguese or foreign, with trips scheduled for RAM, can perform  PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction)  tests at COVID-19,  free of charge ,  in several cities in the country. Currently, there are  33  sample collection stations for testing.    When planning your trip to Madeira and Porto Santo, it is important to know the local rules in force within the scope of the prevention and containment of COVID-19, namely:     1. Epidemiological Survey  All passengers must complete the mandatory epidemiological survey, made available by the Regional Health Authority, on the digital platform madeirasafe.com (...)"    2. Thermal screening  All passengers disembarked at airports in the Autonomous Region of Madeira, without exception, are subject to thermal screening.     3. Test the COVID-19  All passengers who, when disembarking, carry a negative PCR test to COVID-19, carried out within 72 hours prior to boarding, in laboratories certified by national or international authorities, can proceed to their destination.   For their part, passengers who have not undergone PCR testing at the origin will do so on arrival at the airport, then proceed to their destination, where they must wait, in confinement, for the result to be obtained, for an estimated period of 12h (...)     3.1 Children  They are exempt from being subjected to testing in childhood and pre-adolescence, except:     • Children from 12 years old, under the prior opinion of the Health Authorities;  • Children with criteria for suspected COVID disease 19;  • Children whose family members or companions are suspected cases;  • Other situations validated by the Health Authorities.     3.2 Second Test  All travelers residing in the territory of the Autonomous Region of Madeira (RAM), as well as Madeiran emigrants, their families, and students attending higher education establishments or in Mobility Programs, who disembark at Madeira and Porto Santo airports, on flights coming from any territory outside the RAM, they are required to perform the second PCR test to screen for SARS-CoV-2, between the fifth and seventh days after the first test is performed, and must guarantee, in the period between disembarkation and second test, prophylactic isolation at home and full compliance with the surveillance and self-reporting of symptoms and COVID-19 prevention measures.  Travelers / tourists, non-residents, who travel to RAM on a leisure / tourism basis are exempt from this procedure."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213175534/http://www.visitmadeira.pt/pt-pt/info-uteis/corona-virus-%28covid-19%29/informacoes-aos-visitantes-%28covid-19%29    Note: Since during this weekend restrictions apply to the entire Portuguese territory (mainland + Madeira + Azores) the code was upgraded to 2G.

Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210210160304/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus

Thermal screening  All passengers disembarked at airports in the Autonomous Region of Madeira, without exception, are subject to thermal screening.     3. Test the COVID-19  All passengers who, when disembarking, carry a negative PCR test to COVID-19, carried out within 72 hours prior to boarding, in laboratories certified by national or international authorities, can proceed to their destination.   For their part, passengers who have not undergone PCR testing at the origin will do so on arrival at the airport, then proceed to their destination, where they must wait, in confinement, for the result to be obtained, for an estimated period of 12h (...)     3.1 Children  They are exempt from being subjected to testing in childhood and pre-adolescence, except:     • Children from 12 years old, under the prior opinion of the Health Authorities;  • Children with criteria for suspected COVID disease 19;  • Children whose family members or companions are suspected cases;  • Other situations validated by the Health Authorities.     3.2 Second Test  All travelers residing in the territory of the Autonomous Region of Madeira (RAM), as well as Madeiran emigrants, their families, and students attending higher education establishments or in Mobility Programs, who disembark at Madeira and Porto Santo airports, on flights coming from any territory outside the RAM, they are required to perform the second PCR test to screen for SARS-CoV-2, between the fifth and seventh days after the first test is performed, and must guarantee, in the period between disembarkation and second test, prophylactic isolation at home and full compliance with the surveillance and self-reporting of symptoms and COVID-19 prevention measures.  Travelers / tourists, non-residents, who travel to RAM on a leisure / tourism basis are exempt from this procedure."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213175534/http://www.visitmadeira.pt/pt-pt/info-uteis/corona-virus-%28covid-19%29/informacoes-aos-visitantes-%28covid-19%29    Note: Since during this weekend restrictions apply to the entire Portuguese territory (mainland + Madeira + Azores) the code was upgraded to 2G.

Inter-island travel - You should only travel between islands if your journey is essential. If you have to travel and you are travelling from São Miguel to any of the other islands in the archipelago, you will need to have a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before you travel and show the negative result when you board, and complete a passenger questionnaire before you depart    Mainland Portugal: Until further notice, there is a ban on travelling between municipalities at the weekend from 8pm on Friday to 5am the following Monday morning. If you have to travel for essential purposes, such as to go to work or for medical treatment, be prepared to show evidence of the essential nature of your journey, if required to do so by the police.

"Flights to Portugal  Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to:  - European Union countries;  - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland;  - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay.    (...) Flights from the United Kingdom and from Brazil  All commercial or private flights between Portugal and the United Kingdom and between Portugal and Brazil are suspended. Except for the right of entry for national citizens and their families and holders of residence permits in Portugal, only on flights of a humanitarian nature for the purpose of repatriation of those citizens. These passengers will have to present, at the time of departure, proof of a RT-PCR test with a negative result, carried out within 72 hours prior to departure time. Upon arriving in the national territory, they must comply with a period of 14 days of quarantine at home, or in a place indicated by the health authorities.    Flights between Portugal and other destinations will only be permitted for essential travel (from and to non-EU countries or which are not Schengen Associated Countries). In this case, passengers must present a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before departure time."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210226223703/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal
No announced change in policy   https://web.archive.org/web/20210206180005/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/comunicacao/noticias?p=1

Feb 18 - The Council of Ministers approved the decree-law that extends the exceptional support to the family in the scope of the suspension of classroom and non-classroom activities. Exceptional support to the family is extended to workers who are engaged in teleworking and choose to stop their activity to provide assistance to the family, in the following situations:   - single-parent family, during the custody period of the child or other dependent;   - the household includes at least one child or other dependent who is attending social equipment to support early childhood, a pre-school or primary school;   - the household includes at least one dependent with a disability, with a proven disability equal to or greater than 60%, regardless of age.  As a public policy measure that aims to protect the family's income and promote a balance in the provision of assistance to the family, the value of the support is increased when it is alternated weekly between the parents or if it is a single-parent family, with Social Security assuming a differential of up to 100%.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210220191220/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/comunicacao/noticia?i=pais-em-teletrabalho-vao-poder-optar-pela-assistencia-a-familia

"The Portuguese government has approved a moratorium on bank loan repayments for households and companies affected by the coronavirus outbreak which has been extended until end-September 2021. The date by which households and companies can avail themselves of the moratoria was recently extended until the end of March 2021." The measure will cost between 20 and 25 million euros (monthly). For low income families, the reduction in the electricity bill might reach 40%.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118164726/https://eco.sapo.pt/2021/01/12/governo-apoia-familias-com-cerca-de-10-da-fatura-da-luz/    "After a discussion in plenary on December 18, 2020 (...) it became evident that there was a parliamentary majority to guarantee the suspension of the termination of lease agreements, housing and non-housing, until 30 June 2021.    Landlords will not be able to terminate lease agreements, even if the tenancy period has expired, unless there is an agreement with the tenant or the latter fails to pay any rent. This suspension will remain in place until at least June 30, 2021."    Source: https://archive.vn/dK7NP

"Portugal halved testing for covid-19 during the new confinement period (...) The European Center for Disease Control and Prevention (ECDC) released this Thursday the list in the EU (which also includes Norway and Iceland) between weeks 3 and 6 of 2021.    The data analyzed reveal that the Government is not fulfilling its promise to increase the number of tests for covid-19. In fact, the number of tests has been declining over the past month. In the last four weeks alone, the testing rate in Portugal has dropped from 4,300 tests per 100,000 inhabitants to 2,100 per 100,000 inhabitants.    These figures translate into a difference of minus 232,751 tests with covid-19 over the last month. The rate of positivity has also dropped considerably.    Part of the decrease in testing for covid-19 in Portugal may be related to the new widespread confinement, since the large part of the population remains at home. It should also be noted that the rule that extends the testing of SARS-CoV-2 to all contacts in Portugal, including the performance of molecular tests to low risk “at the time of identification” of the contact, was published on February 12 by the Portuguese General Directorate of Health (DGS).    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210220065320/https://tvi24.iol.pt/sociedade/ecdc/covid-19-portugal-reduziu-a-testagem-para-metade-durante-novo-confinamento    "Hospital da Luz Lisboa now has a Covid-19 Drive Thru Test available (...) medical prescription is not required".    Source: https://archive.vn/csrQg    Note: The code can be subjected to interpretation: drive-thrus are available everywhere - these were available even prior to the confinement for those who wanted to get tested (e.g. travel)-, however, the number of tests have been decreasing (due to the confinement - since most people stay at home - and the significant reduction in cases). No evidence that there is a lack of tests available was found.
No policy change  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206180403/https://www.tsf.pt/portugal/sociedade/rede-alternativa-de-rastreio-recupera-atraso-no-norte-e-expande-se-a-lisboa-13309723.html

Marta Temido said that the screening capacity for Covid-19 cases almost tripled between December 2020 and February 2021, noting that “on December 13, the number of full-time professionals carrying out epidemiological surveys was 427 and on February 4 it was over 1100 "with" officials from central and local administration, students and members of the security and armed forces "conducting these inquiries. Epidemiological surveys have been simplified and the "adoption of collaborative models" allows "in most of the country" contact with people to be made within the first 24 hours. Phase 1 From December 2020: Health professionals involved in patient care, Professionals in the armed forces, security forces and critical services, Professionals and residents in Residential Structures for the Elderly (ERPI) and similar institutions, Professionals and users of the National Integrated, Continuing Care Network (RNCCI).    From February 2021 : People aged =50 years, with at least one of the following pathologies: Cardiac insufficiency Coronary heart disease, Renal insufficiency (Glomerular Filtration Rate <60ml / min)  (COPD) or chronic respiratory disease under ventilatory support and / or long-term oxygen therapy.  People aged 80 and over.    The Prime Minister said "this week we started the second part of the first phase, now addressing everyone over 50 years old who have a set of associated diseases and to the entire population over 80 years old, and also to all those who provide essential services to the country, namely those who work in the security forces and services "    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210206180604/https://covid19estamoson.gov.pt/vacinacao-covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206180731/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/comunicacao/noticia?i=comeca-vacinacao-das-forcas-de-seguranca-armadas-e-de-trabalhadores-de-servicos-essenciais

From February 2021 :  - People aged =50 years, with at least one of the following pathologies: Cardiac insufficiency, Coronary heart disease, Renal insufficiency or chronic respiratory disease under ventilatory support and / or long-term oxygen therapy  - People aged 80 and over.    Vaccines: The covid-19 vaccines that Portugal purchased are, according to Infarmed, as follows: 6.9 million doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine, 4.5 million from Johnson & Johnson, 4.5 million from Pfizer, 4/5 million from CureVac, 1.8 million from Moderna and number of doses to be determined from the Sanofi-GSK vaccine.    Feb 19 - If in the early days orders arrived more widely, since there was only one type of vaccine approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA), that of Pfizer, in recent weeks they have arrived more frequently, given that in addition to the aforementioned company, there are two other different types of vaccines approved in the European Union: the Moderna vaccine, approved on 6 January, and the AstaZeneca / Oxford, approved on 29 January. According to the ministerial order 3090/8.01.2021, teaching activities that require the physical presence in preschool, primary, secondary, high school and post-secondary education units are suspended for the period 11th-29th of January 2021. Between 30th of January and 7th of February, schoolchildren and preschoolers have inter-semester vacation.  Links: https://archive.fo/wip/dYf7v, https://archive.fo/r0SkT and https://archive.fo/REcKf

According to the ministerial order no.3.235/93/04.02.2021, depending on the incidence rate by localities, the activity of the educational units will be organized, starting with 8th of February, in three scenarios: a) Physical presence for all categories, if the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days in the locality is less or equal to 1/1000 people; b) physical presence for preschool, primary, 8th, 12th and 13th classes, and online presence for the other classes, for a incidence less or equal with 3/1000; c) Online presence for all categories, except preschool and primary units, if incidence is higher than 3/1000.  Links: https://archive.fo/wip/H8lox

According to the ministerial order no.3.235/93/04.02.2021, depending on the incidence rate by localities, the activity of the educational units will be organized, starting with 8th of February, in three scenarios: a) Physical presence for all categories, if the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days in the locality is less or equal to 1/1000 people; b) physical presence for preschool, primary, 8th, 12th and 13th classes, and online presence for the other classes, for a incidence less or equal with 3/1000; c) Online presence for all categories, except preschool and primary units, if incidence is higher than 3/1000.  Links: https://archive.fo/wip/H8lox

Romania began to reopen schools on 8 February, three months after the Government closed schools throughout the country to limit the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.    There are 3 scenarios for reopening schools based on the epidemiological situation in each locality:    The green scenario, which applies to towns with low incidence rates of COVID-19, allows all children to return to school.    The yellow scenario, which applies to cities with moderate incidence rates, only kindergarten children and primary school (I-IV grades) pupils return to school, plus those in the eighth and twelfth grades, who have to prepare for the national exams.    The red scenario, which applies in localities with incidence rates of over 3 per 1,000 inhabitants (over a 14-day period), only kindergarten and primary school children return to school.    Students who can’t return to school, either due to the yellow or red scenarios, will continue online courses, which have been going on for most of the first semester.    Currently, the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is over 3 per 1,000 occupants in Timis and Maramures counties, therefore, these counties are in the red scenario.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211716/https://www.romaniajournal.ro/society-people/education/physical-classes-in-schools-resumed-as-of-february-8/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211543/https://www.edu.ro/sites/default/files/ordin%20comun%20nr.%203.235_93_4.02.2021.pdf    https://archive.fo/85fHU

As of 15 February, the ban on indoor operation for bars, clubs, and disco activities remains in place.    Cinemas, performance institutions, indoor restaurants, indoor cafés, and gambling halls are allowed to operate under the following conditions:    Without exceeding 50% of the maximum capacity of the space and only in the time interval 6.00-23.00, in the counties/localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is less than or equal to 1.5/1,000 inhabitants.    Without exceeding 30% of the maximum capacity of the space and only in the time interval 6.00-23.00, if the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days of the cases in the county/locality is higher than 1.5 and less than or equal to 3/1,000 inhabitants.    It is forbidden if the cumulative incidence of cases is higher than 3/1,000 inhabitants.    Currently, the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is over 3 per 1,000 occupants in Timis and Maramures counties, therefore, cinemas, performance institutions, indoor restaurants, indoor cafés, and gambling halls are closed in these counties.     Museums, art galleries, libraries, and bookstores are open with social distancing and mask requirements. Disinfection of hands and a temperature check is required before entering.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211825/https://stirioficiale.ro/conduita    https://archive.fo/85fHU

The organization and outdoor performance of shows, concerts, public and private festivals or other cultural events is allowed in counties/localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is less than or equal to 1.5/1,000 inhabitants.     Events are limited to 300 spectators with seats located at a distance of at least 2 meters apart. Protective masks are also required.    Activities are prohibited in counties/localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is higher than 1.5/1,000 inhabitants.    Currently the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is higher than 1.5/1,000 occupants in Timis, Maramures, Cluj, Brasov, Ilfov, Bucharest, Alba, Hunedoara, Satu Mare, Sibiu, Salaj, and Gorj counties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211825/https://stirioficiale.ro/conduita    https://archive.fo/85fHU

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours. The Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 (extended through Decision 58/10.12.20) of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance). The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities. Link: https://archive.fo/cUlEp,  https://archive.fo/T7Aib, https://web.archive.org/web/20201212161456/https://www.gov.ro/fisiere/pagini_fisiere/Hotarare_CNSU_nr._58_din_10.12.2020.pdf  and https://archive.fo/4mnCH

Throughout Romania, it is forbidden for people to be outside the home between 23.00 - 05.00, with the following exceptions:    Travel in the professional interest, including between home / household and the place / places where the professional activity takes place and back.    Travel for medical care that cannot be postponed or performed remotely, as well as for the purchase of medicines.    Travel outside the locality of persons who are in transit or make journeys whose time interval overlaps with the prohibition period such as those made by plane, train, coach or other means of passenger transport and which can be proved by ticket or any another way to pay for the trip.    Travel for justified reasons, such as caring for / accompanying the child, assisting the elderly, sick or disabled or the death of a family member.    In order to justify moving away from home during this period, citizens must have on them the declaration on their own responsibility, the certificate from the employer or the service card (the last two can only be used to justify moving for professional purposes).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211825/https://stirioficiale.ro/conduita

On 15 February, the updated list of high epidemiological risk states was implemented. The list now includes 67 states, compared to 65 on 4 February.    Upon entering Romania, travelers arriving from countries on this list are required to quarantine for 14 days. Those who submit a PCR test no later than 72 hours before entry must quarantine for 10 days.    "Upon entering Romania, for persons arriving from countries / areas / territories of high epidemiological risk and presents a document attesting the negative result of an RT-PCR test for SARS-CoV virus infection-2, made no later than 72 hours before boarding (for those traveling by public transport) or entering the national territory (for those traveling by own means), the quarantine measure is established at home or at the location declared for a period of 10 days."      Economic operators that carry out international, air and road transport of persons, by regular or irregular flights to Romania from high epidemiological risk areas have the obligation to prohibit the embarkation in the means of transport of persons who do not present a document certifying:    The negative result of an RT-PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, performed no more than 72 hours before boarding, or    The vaccination against the SARS-CoV-2 virus, including the second dose, and for which at least 10 days have elapsed since its administration until the date of embarkation, or    That they have been confirmed positive for SARS-CoV-2 virus infection in the last 90 days prior to embarkation and that at least 14 days have elapsed from the date of confirmation to the date of embarkation. The proof of confirmation is made with medical documents such as: positive RT-PCR test at the date of diagnosis, hospital discharge ticket or test proving the presence of IgG antibodies performed up to 14 days before entering the country, as well as other documents supporting documents.      All travelers arriving in Romania who have been fully vaccinated from COVID-19 are exempt from quarantining on arrival.    The second dose must have been administered at least 10 days prior to their arrival.    "The vaccination proof, including the date when the second dose was administered, should be made through the document issued by the health unit that administered it, whether that be in Romania or abroad," the CNSU said in a statement.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210219224903/https://www.news.ro/social/update-cnsu-actualizat-lista-zonelor-risc-epidemiologic-ridicat-stabilit-regulile-aplicare-masurii-carantinei-asupra-persoanelor-sosesc-acestea-persoanele-prezinta-test-pcr-negativ-stau-carantina-10-1922404011002021022219971215    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219225551/https://i0.1616.ro/media/2/2701/33586/19971215/3/anexa-la-hotararea-cnsu-nr-9.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219232637/https://www.cnn.com/travel/article/countries-open-to-vaccinated-travelers/index.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220034758/https://stirioficiale.ro/hotarari/hotararea-nr-9-din-11-02-2021-cnsu

The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

On 4 December, the provisions of articles XI and XV of the Government Emergency Ordinance No. 30/2020 for establishing measures in the field of social protection in the context of the epidemiological situation determined by the spread of SARS-CoV-2 was extended until 30 June 2021.    Article XI states that as a result of the effects produced by the SARS-CoV-2, the allowances that benefit employees are set at 75% of the basic salary corresponding to the job occupied and are borne from the unemployment insurance budget, but not more than 75% of the average gross earnings provided.     Article XV states that other professionals, as well as persons who have concluded individual labor agreements which are interrupted as a result of the effects of the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 during the state of emergency, benefits from the state budget, based on the declaration on its own responsibility, a monthly allowance of 75% of the average gross earnings provided by law on the state social insurance budget.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201125000054/http://legislatie.just.ro/Public/DetaliiDocumentAfis/225659    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220043552/http://legislatie.just.ro/Public/DetaliiDocumentAfis/234289

On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers. According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://archive.fo/hVM21

On 1 January 2021, Emergency Ordinance No. 227 went into effect.    The bank's clients, individuals with ongoing loans, whose income was directly or indirectly affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, can benefit from the facility to suspend the payment of installments according to GEO 37/2020 as amended by GEO 227/2020 .    The total period of suspension of payment obligations for a loan is a maximum of 9 months and includes: the periods of suspension requested and granted until 15 June 2020 based on GEO 37/2020, the periods of suspension granted based on a private moratorium and the periods of suspension requested after the entry into force of GEO 227/2020.    Under these conditions, only clients who have not already benefited from the maximum deferral period for payment based on the public moratorium established by GEO 37/2020 and / or based on a private moratorium are eligible.       In order to benefit from the suspension of payments according to GEO 37/2020 as amended by GEO 227/2020, the following criteria must be met:    Individual’s income and / or family income has been affected by the situation generated by the COVID-19 pandemic compared to the level registered before the declaration of the state of emergency and is are unable to honor the payment obligations related to the credit.     15 March is the application deadline, inclusive.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220061111/http://legislatie.just.ro/Public/DetaliiDocument/235875    https://web.archive.org/web/20200507141027/https://www.raiffeisen.ro/persoane-fizice/in-sprijinul-tau/asistenta/suspendare-rate-credite/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220062628/https://www.unicredit.ro/ro/persoane-fizice/Diverse/covid-19.html

On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”. On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases. Also, the National Information Platform on vaccination against COVID-19 was released. As of 20 February, the official government website for COVID-19 remains current. (https://stirioficiale.ro/informatii). Daily updates, press releases, current restrictions, statistics, educational videos, hygiene recommendations, advice for parents, and answers to frequently asked questions are provided on the website.     Individuals can also subscribe to an official email newsletter for updates and important information.     Chrome and Firefox web browser extensions have been created by the Code for Romania Task Force. The purpose of the extensions are to highlight official sources of information in order to reduce the effects of 'fake news'. The extension identifies key phrases related to COVID-19 and adds an info box that links to official sources    RoVaccinare is the official platform for information regarding vaccination against COVID-19 in Romania (vaccinare-covid.gov.ro). The website provides news, information on authorized vaccines, the vaccination process in Romania, and corrects misinformation surrounding vaccines.     A helpline has been established for individuals with symptoms and for those with questions about the transmission and spread of the virus (0800 800 358).    Additional information is also provided on the Ministry of Health’s website (www.ms.ro/coronavirus-covid-19).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210220205733/https://stirioficiale.ro/informatii    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220211201/https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/covid-19-stiri-oficiale/pdcpkplohipjhdfdchpmgekifmcdbnha    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219140826/https://vaccinare-covid.gov.ro/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118094602/https://cetrebuiesafac.ro/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220231150/https://stirioficiale.ro/informatii/buletin-de-presa-19-februarie-2021-ora-13-00

As of 20 February, individuals with symptoms should call a family doctor who will make a telephone assessment and decide the way forward. If the doctor decides that a COVID-19 test is needed, the individual will be instructed to call the Public Health Directorate and mention all symptoms.    The ambulance service will go to the individual’s house to perform the test, or if the situation requires it, will transport the individual to the hospital.    In the case of symptomatic people, the test is done according to the protocol, free of charge.    Individuals can also get tested "on request", but this option is for a fee.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118094602/https://cetrebuiesafac.ro/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219215935/https://ro.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive. The Government of Romania has defined “close contact” with COVID-19 infected individuals to facilitate epidemiological investigations.    The purpose of defining close contact to identify individuals designated for 14-day self-isolation following close contact with a COVID-19 confirmed infection.    During the period of self-isolation, “close contact” individuals will be tested at the beginning and end of the two-week period. The epidemiological investigation should not lead to the supervised isolation of other individuals not meeting “close contact” criteria.    This includes:  Persons living in the same household as a confirmed COVID-19 patient.    Persons with direct physical contact with confirmed patients.    Persons with unprotected direct contact (i.e. coughing)    Persons in the same room (i.e. students) with a confirmed patient for a minimum of 15 minutes at a distance less than 2 meters.    Medical personnel providing direct care to confirmed patients without proper protective equipment.      On 11 February, a teacher from Salaj County was confirmed with COVID-19, this being the first case of infection since the resumption of face-to-face courses. Students will go to school online for 14 days.    The representatives of the Salaj Public Health Directorate started the epidemiological investigation, in order to establish direct contacts of the teacher, and will decide together with the management of the educational unit if quarantine is required.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210219215935/https://ro.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220215742/https://adevarul.ro/locale/zalau/primul-cadru-didactic-infectat-reluarea-cursurilor-autoritatile-demarat-ancheta-epidemiologica-1_60251ec05163ec4271dedab2/index.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220215946/http://www.ms.ro/2020/10/28/se-modifica-fluxul-informational-utilizat-in-raportarea-datelor-referitoare-la-infectia-cu-virusul-sars-cov-2/

As of 20 February, stage 2 of the vaccination campaign against COVID is ongoing. Vaccines are provided at no cost to the individual.     Between 18 February at 17:00 and 19 February at 17:00, 28,019 Pfizer vaccines, 671 Moderna vaccines, and 9,438 AstraZeneca vaccines were administered.    Stage 2 includes adults over the age of 65; persons with chronic diseases, regardless of age, according to the indications of the vaccines used; persons with a degree of disability, immobilized persons, immunocompromised persons, their companions and persons living in the same household with them; homeless people; essential workers.    On 20 February, the coordinator of the vaccination campaign against COVID, military doctor Valeriu Gheorghita, said that stage 3 of the vaccination campaign could start in April, and registration would start in March.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222235341/https://vaccinare-covid.gov.ro/actualizare-zilnica-19-02-evidenta-persoanelor-vaccinate-impotriva-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222235113/https://www.digi24.ro/stiri/actualitate/sanatate/valeriu-gheorghita-a-anuntat-cand-va-incepe-vaccinarea-persoanelor-din-etapa-a-iii-a-1455320?__grsc=cookieIsUndef0&__grts=53801262&__grua=915fe5f49a696a6a12f1f7d93c029921&__grrn=1    https://web.archive.org/web/20210201234335/https://vaccinare-covid.gov.ro/vaccinarea-sars-cov-2/procesul-de-vaccinare-in-romania/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210223000515/https://vaccinare-covid.gov.ro/resurse/intrebari-si-raspunsuri/

According to the Decree ? 2393 from 31 December 2020, the government extended the maximum amount of unemployment benefits until the end of 2021 due to COVID-19. The maximum allowance will remain at 12,130 rubles. In the first three months, an unemployed citizen will be paid 75 percent of lost salary, and the second three months – 60 percent of lost salary.   It should be mentioned that in March 2020 the maximum amount of unemployment benefits was increased from 8,000 rubles to 12,130 rubles. Initially, this was a temporary government measure to support unemployed citizens during COVID-19. However, at the end of 2020, the government decided to keep the maximum allowance in 2021 at the same level as before. On October 28th, the government of the Russian Federation reinstated a requirement to wear masks in crowded public areas, including public transportation, taxis, parking lots, and elevators.  This order applies to the entire country. Regions and cities set their own fines for violating rules on social distancing, wearing masks, etc.  In Moscow, individuals not wearing masks and gloves on public transportation or in stores may be fined 5,000 rubles. C:    From 26 January remarks:  Currently, most people are being vaccinated with Sputnik V. Next month we will switch to the large-scale production of EpiVacCorona. It is already being introduced into civilian circulation. The Government has earmarked over 2 billion roubles for its manufacture.  The Healthcare Ministry has received documents for registering one more vaccine. It was developed by the Chumakov Centre. This is already a third vaccine developed by our scientists. It will go into civilian circulation in the next few months. All this will allow us to expand vaccination and make it more accessible, thereby protecting more people against the coronavirus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210131221853/http://government.ru/en/news/41389/

From 18 January 2021, Russia launched a mass vaccination policy for free. Everyone 18+can receive a vaccine on a voluntary basis. It should be mentioned that during December only elderly people, medical workers, and people with chronic diseases had an opportunity to receive vaccines. Now, there are no such restrictions. Since the vaccination on a voluntary basis and the number of people to get vaccinated only increasing.      Links: https://archive.vn/kmTXE https://archive.vn/jkeWX https://archive.vn/qTPC4 https://archive.vn/0s2lb

In addition Russia started administering the coronavirus vaccine to homeless people on 21 February 2021.   Sputnik V is mostly used.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222174642/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/02/22/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-feb-21-a69117

Sputnik V most widely administered. EpiVacCorons and KoviVak are approved for widespread use.  In the third week of February, another vaccine against COVID-19- "KoviliVak" developed by the Chumakov Ras Center was registered. It was the third vaccine to be approved for widespread use in our country after Sputnik V from the Gamalea Research Center and EpiVacCorons developed by Vector.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227203554/https://xn--80aesfpebagmfblc0a.xn--p1ai/news/20210227-1901.html    Broad availability has not yet been achieved:   However, not all the problems of mass vaccination have been solved so far. The day before, the head of the Ministry of Health Mikhail Murashko said that the regional authorities should actively encourage older citizens to be vaccinated, as in some regions the proportion of vaccinated residents over 60 years remains low.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227202910/https://xn--80aesfpebagmfblc0a.xn--p1ai/news/20210226-1942.html

Starting Monday, 08 February, Slovakia will adopt the COVID-19 "Automat" Traffic Light System, which will update pandemic control measures regionally based on predetermined criteria.  Anyone physically present in a district in the black or dark red phase must carry with them outside their homes proof of a negative test less than 7 days old, a complete vaccination (two doses, plus 14 days have passed since the second dose), or proof of recovery from COVID-19 not more than three months ago.      As of 05 February, all of Slovakia is in the black phase.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206202810/https://korona.gov.sk/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/ciastka_19_2021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206200912/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206202439/https://sk.usembassy.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/193/Feb-5-Traffic-Light-System.pdf    For schools, no policy changes until 08 February, when some schools will be allowed to re-open.  As of 05 Friday, there was indication that some municipalities may choose not to re-open.    School guidelines in black phase:  - Kindergarten, Primary 1-4 grades - in person  - Primary, Secondary - only ending grades - in person  - Testing required  - University – online    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206203735/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22588626/news-digest-slovakia-will-follow-new-rules-from-monday-children-will-return-to-schools.html?ref=njctse  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206204158/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22590217/news-digest-british-variant-widespread-across-the-country.html

From 08 February, some schools decided to physically re-open, while others decided to stay with distance education.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210213192819/https://bratislavskykraj.sk/v-malackach-sa-skoly-otvarat-nebudu-pokracuju-v-distancnom-vzdelavani/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210213192940/https://bratislavskykraj.sk/prezencne-vyucovanie-sa-obnovilo-na-styroch-zupnych-skolach/

No policy changes until 15 February, when some districts will move to the Warning II (pink) and Warning III (red) phases from the Warning IV (black) phase, where all of Slovakia is currently designated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210213192631/https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanok?covid-19-11-02-2021-okresy-rozdelenie  https://web.archive.org/web/20210213191559/https://korona.gov.sk/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/83_2021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210213190944/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of 17 February, there is still evidence that some schools have continued to not return to in-person teaching.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220215412/https://bratislavskykraj.sk/az-polovica-rodicov-je-za-obnovenie-prezencnej-vyucby/

Starting Monday, 08 February, Slovakia will adopt the COVID-19 Traffic Light System, which will update pandemic control measures regionally based on predetermined criteria.  Anyone physically present in a district in the black or dark red phase must carry with them outside their homes proof of a negative test less than 7 days old, a complete vaccination (two doses, plus 14 days have passed since the second dose), or proof of recovery from COVID-19 not more than three months ago.      As of 05 February, all of Slovakia is in the black phase.    Businesses and Organizations in black phase:  - Home-office ordered whenever possible, tests control    Recreational sporting in black phase:  - Based on activity risks (specified separately)    Skiing resorts in black phase:  - Not allowed    Fitness centers in black phase:  - Not allowed    Wellness, Aqua Parks, Spas in black phase:  - Not allowed    Pools Indoor/Outdoor in black phase:  - Not allowed    Stores, Services, and Shopping Malls in black phase:  - Only essential stores and services open, max 1 person per 15m2    Restaurants in black phase:  - Take-away or delivery only    Museums, Galleries, and Exhibition Halls in black phase:  - Closed    Libraries in black phase:  - Closed    Hospitality in black phase:  - Not allowed except for quarantine facilities and facilities for critical infrastructure members long term    Taxi in black phase:  - Max 2 passengers, only back seats, masks, regular air ventilation, disinfection after each client    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206202810/https://korona.gov.sk/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/ciastka_19_2021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206200912/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206202439/https://sk.usembassy.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/193/Feb-5-Traffic-Light-System.pdf

No policy changes until 15 February, when some districts will move to the Warning II (pink) and Warning III (red) phases from the Warning IV (black) phase, where all of Slovakia is currently designated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210213192631/https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanok?covid-19-11-02-2021-okresy-rozdelenie  https://web.archive.org/web/20210213191559/https://korona.gov.sk/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/83_2021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210213190944/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From 15 February through 21 February, the Slovak national indicator remains Warning IV (black) phase. Regional district indictors are Warning II (pink), Warning III (red), and Warning IV (black). With the exception of testing and internal movement, since the Warning II, III, and IV phases have similar restrictions, there are no changes to coding and keeping the consistency between general and targeted coding for now.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220212708/https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanok?covid-19-11-02-2021-okresy-rozdelenie  https://web.archive.org/web/20210220210204/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Anyone physically present in a district in the black or dark red phase must carry with them outside their homes proof of a negative test less than 7 days old, a complete vaccination (two doses, plus 14 days have passed since the second dose), or proof of recovery from COVID-19 not more than three months ago.      As of 05 February, all of Slovakia is in the black phase.    Mass Events guidelines in black phase:  - Not allowed    Alcohol Consumption in Public in black phase:  - Not allowed    Professional sporting in black phase:  - Not allowed    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206202810/https://korona.gov.sk/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/ciastka_19_2021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206200912/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206202439/https://sk.usembassy.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/193/Feb-5-Traffic-Light-System.pdf
