From 15 February 2021, all of Slovenia will be considered Orange. This means that the following rules apply across the country:  - All kindergartens, primary schools, adult education centres and vocational high schools will open for face to face classes. High School senior students will also attend classes in person.    Link: https://archive.vn/5fDPt
Previously-cited change in policy doesn't take effect until 15 February. Extending current indicator for this date.    https://archive.vn/5fDPt

Lessons can now take place on school premises for elementary school pupils, vocational secondary school students and final year secondary school students. For other students, distance learning is being carried out.    https://archive.vn/ujoen

From 6 February, libraries, museums, galleries and outdoor cultural heritage sites are permitted to open across the country.  The following domestic measures also remain in effect:  - Nonessential businesses and facilities are closed; businesses that are permitted to open must implement strict hygiene and social distancing measures.  - Restaurants, cafes, and bars may only offer carryout services.  - Facemasks are mandatory in all nonrural public spaces.    From 15 February 2021, all of Slovenia will be considered Orange. The following rules apply across the country:  - A wider range of shops and services are open. Some services will only be allowed to open if they provide weekly testing for their staff. Consumers are not required to provide a negative Covid-19 test to access any services that are open.  - Hotels are closed, with a few limited exemptions to allow for business/diplomatic stays or for professional sports teams.  - Restaurants and bars are closed. Takeaway services are open and permitted.  Link: https://archive.vn/5fDPt
No change in policy.    https://archive.vn/ujoen

A temporary ban on gathering is being imposed throughout the Republic of Slovenia. Temporarily are prohibited all events, gatherings, celebrations, weddings and religious ceremonies.   Link: https://archive.vn/508cI
No change in policy.    https://archive.vn/ujoen

A temporary ban on gathering is being imposed throughout the Republic of Slovenia. Temporarily are prohibited all events, gatherings, celebrations, weddings and religious ceremonies. Gathering is permitted only to groups of persons who are close family members or share the same household.    Public gatherings: Gatherings outside of a household are limited to 10 persons and still require proper precautions such as masks.    Link: https://archive.vn/508cI  https://archive.vn/QeWgS
No change in policy.    https://archive.vn/ujoen

Public passenger transport is to be carried out to the registered extent in the whole of Slovenia.. All passengers using public transport are obliged to wear masks, disinfect hands and comply with the rules regarding entry and exit from vehicles. All passengers are advised to purchase their tickets in advance.  Link: https://archive.vn/508cI    Internal train/bus service: Limited service (holiday schedules).  Passengers must disinfect their hands upon entry, wear a face mask and keep a safety distance of at least 1.5 meters.  The Infrastructure Ministry has established a hotline at 01 478 85 12 to address questions on public transportation.    Link: https://archive.vn/QeWgS
Updating indicator.    Public passenger transport can be carried out in accordance with the normal timetables. Masks are mandatory on public transport.    https://archive.vn/ujoen

TO REVIEWERS - suggest revision of previous scores    Restriction of movement between 21:00 and 6:00. Movement of people on the entire territory of the Republic of Slovenia is temporarily prohibited between 22:00 and 6:00 with the following exceptions:  - the elimination of immediate threats to health, life and property;  - travel to and from work and the performance of urgent work duties;  - access to and provision of emergency services;  - delivery of food or medicines;  - the travel of persons who have entered the Republic of Slovenia in order to transit to a neighbouring country or to their residence in the Republic of Slovenia.    Link: https://archive.vn/508cI

Updating indicator.    A curfew is in place across the nation: Movement of people on the entire territory of the Republic of Slovenia is temporarily prohibited between 22:00 and 6:00.    https://archive.vn/ujoen

Movement between municipalities is prohibited with certain exceptions for which adequate proof must be submitted.  Movement between municipalities is allowed in the following cases:  - travel to and from work and the performance of work duties;  - the performance of business, agricultural and forestry activities;  - the elimination of immediate threats to health, life and property;  -the provision of care and assistance to persons in need of support, care of family members, or ---parental care or contact with one’s children;  -access to pharmacies, health and sanitary services, and health resort treatment;  -access to foreign diplomatic missions and consular posts;  -access to emergency services;  -access to the performance of tasks related to the operation of judicial, administrative and law enforcement authorities;  -access to services for persons with special needs;  -the performance of maintenance work or seasonal chores on private property for members of the -same household;  -the travel of persons who have entered the Republic of Slovenia in order to transit to a neighbouring country or to their residence in the Republic of Slovenia;  -access to shops or services in another municipality that are closer to the person's residence than the same shops and services in the municipality of their residence or if there are no such shops or services in their municipality;  - urgent maintenance of a grave, in which case the person must demonstrate their eligibility with proof of burial plot lease or other appropriate proof.  -Exceptions also apply to immediate family members  (spouses, cohabiting partners, partners living in formal or non-formal civil unions, divorced spouses or partners whose maintenance was recognised by a court decision, their parents, children) and members of the same household when travelling together.    Link: https://archive.vn/508cI
Change in policy doesn't take effect until 15 February. Extending current indicator for this date.    https://archive.vn/5fDPt
From 15 February 2021, movement between municipalities and regions is permitted again.    https://archive.vn/5fDPt

As of Feb. 12, individuals arriving from most EEA countries or Switzerland must produce proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test result in order to enter the country; alternatively, they can enter self-isolation for 14 days. However, a PCR test may be taken after eight days, and a negative result will end the isolation period.    Individuals arriving from high-risk non-EU countries must register with authorities and self-isolate for at least eight days, after which a COVID-19 test may be taken; those testing positive are required to self-isolate until they have recovered. Cross-border commuters are not required to self-isolate, though they must be in possession of a negative PCR or antigen COVID-19 test result taken within the previous seven days.     In addition, from Feb. 13, international arrivals who can provide evidence that they have been vaccinated against COVID-19 with two doses or have previously recovered from the virus will be permitted to enter without self-isolation or testing.    Individuals arriving from countries designated as low risk may enter without restriction; these countries include Australia, China, Finland, Iceland, New Zealand, Norway, Singapore, South Korea, and Taiwan.    Link: https://archive.vn/4hToZ  https://archive.vn/kjSkg
No change in policy.    Red list countries must quarantine for 10 days upon arrival in Slovenia.    https://archive.vn/vntaj

On February 3, 2021, an eight package (EUR 320 mn) was approved, which extends the furlough till April and the short-time work scheme till June. The wage subsidy under the furlough was increased from 80 to 100 percent under certain conditions. In addition, the government will cover part of the minimum wage increase for affected businesses and will pay one-off allowances to certain vulnerable groups.  Additional extended measures into 2021 to be found here: https://archive.vn/vYODR  Link: https://archive.vn/WkKzU
No change in current policy.    https://archive.vn/u2hw9

Measures related to public guarantees  - The public guarantee scheme with impact beyond 2020 (loans with maturity up to 5 years).  - The deferral of loans by up to 12 months with impact beyond 2020. The sixth anti-corona package allows for additional deferral of loans for 9 months in 2021 (the applications can be submitted to the bank until end of February 2021) in order to mitigate as much as possible the negative consequences of the second COVID-19 epidemic on the economy.  - State guarantees of EUR 30m for bank loans for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, and the reduction of bank costs and of EUR 100 million to cover the first loss of the financial engineering measure in the field of tourism and catering. The measure is implemented by the Public Fund of the Republic of Slovenia for Entrepreneurship and the SID bank  Link: https://archive.vn/vYODR

Testing is available for both foreign nationals and Slovenians.  No appointment is required for the rapid antigen tests (RAT), and they are available throughout the country, including Ljubljana airport.  For the PCR test, available at the Ljubljana Clinical Center, an appointment is required, but is usually available within a day.  For foreign nationals, cost for RAT is 25-30 euro; cost for PCR is 93 euro.  Results for both tests will be provided to you electronically within 24 hours.     Link: https://archive.vn/QeWgS

Masks or other forms of protection covering mouth and nose are mandatory: in all closed public spaces, on public transport, in open public spaces or outside and in personal vehicles.    Link: https://archive.vn/40rHj

Pfizer/BionTech & Moderna & AstraZeneca vaccines     The vaccination of people older than 80 continues throughout the country today, including in Ljubljana and Ajdovšcina.    Vaccination is free for all citizens, regardless of whether they are insured or not. Funds for the purchase of vaccines and costs for vaccination are provided in the budget of the Republic of Slovenia.    5 Feb -  Slovenia started vaccinating the elderly in care homes first, as care homes recorded frequent outbreaks and suffered the most fatalities. Apart from the elderly, nursing home and hospital staff are also being vaccinated in Slovenia at the moment.    The country has also recently received the first batch of a vaccine developed by AstraZeneca, which is, however, recommended for a younger population.       Link: https://archive.vn/cwvre  https://archive.vn/OFLYU  https://archive.vn/hH21B

"The current recommendation for upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor, usually for 16-18-year olds) to switch to remote learning was extended until April 1st.    From Monday January 25th however it will be adapted so that schools may have some parts of teaching in-person, in combination with distance learning."     https://www.thelocal.se/20210122/swedish-public-health-agency-wear-medical-masks-on-public-transport-not-cloth-masks

The Public Health Agency has recommended that, for the period of 25 Jan-1 April, upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) conduct their education partially as distance education and partially at school. This does not include exams which cannot be taken at a distance and vulnerable students. The decision is at the discretion of the school principal, who has a certain flexibility to make decisions about their activities based on the current infection control situation or local needs, which is why this is coded with a Targeted flag.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210204142817/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen

At the federal level, the Public Health Agency recommends that, for the period of 25 Jan-1 April, upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) conduct their education partially as distance education and partially at school. Whether to switch to distance learning depends on infection rates.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210226195119/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    At the regional level, therefore, on 25 February, several regional 'Infection Control Units' (Smittskyd) recommended to switch distance learning entirely for the senior level of compulsory school (högstadieskolor) and upper-secondary schools (gymnasieskolor). This concerns in the regions of Halland, Kalmar, Kronoberg, Skåne, Stockholm, Skellefteå, Västmanland and Västra Götaland, where infection rates are rising.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210226195551/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/regional-information-about-coronavirus

No change: the temporary shutdown of public buildings continues, so that all activities within the state, municipalities and regions that are not necessary should remain closed until 7 February 2021. This applies, for example, to bathhouses, sports halls and museums.    Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person is given ten square meters of space. The companies must display clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.       There are extensive hygiene measures in place for restaurants, cafés and pubs. The serving of alcoholic beverages and alcoholic beverage-like preparations is prohibited between 20.00 and 11.00 until 7 February 2021.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210204143008/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Public buildings have reopened on 8th February. Most workplaces can open with special measures in place, but a number of workplaces are forced to close in relation to the ban on public gatherings of over 8 people, such as fairground amusements and parades, and markets and fairs.     Restaurants, cafés and pubs can open, but the size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to four people. If a party is larger than eight people, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them. The serving of alcoholic beverages is prohibited between 20.00 and 11.00.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212174105/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Additionally:   On 26 February, the Public Health Agency decided that from 1 March, restaurants will need to close at 20.30. This applies regardless of whether alcohol is served or not. Take-away remains possible.     The Public Health Agency maintains a dialogue with the business community about further limiting the number of visitors to shops and malls and about infection control measures at workplaces. The Swedish Public Health Agency is also working to tighten the rules for sports.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210226211107/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/februari/fler-atgarder-for-att-minska-smittspridningen/

No change: public gatherings and events may have a maximum of eight participants. The police can cancel or disband a public gathering or event with more participants. No change: http://web.archive.org/web/20210204143911/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions    Note for next coder: From 6 February, a travel ban on all countries will be introduced, as well as a requirement for a negative Covid-19 test certificate for foreign citizens. The test result must not be older than 48 hours. The new rules supplement the previous entry ban. There will be relaxations and exemptions, including for cross-border workers.

The Swedish Government has decided to stop non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban will be in effect until March 31. This ban has been introduced to mitigate the effects of the coronavirus outbreak, and to reduce the spread of Covid-19.   The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. Moreover, the ban does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.  A temporary ban on entry to Sweden for nationals from the UK, Denmark and Norway is in effect.    Exceptions may be made, such as for:  •    Anyone working or living in Sweden can enter from Denmark.  •    Children going to meet parents living in Sweden and their escort.  •    Those travelling in health service vehicles.    In addition to the entry ban, foreign nationals need to present a negative Covid-19 test result no older than 48h in order to travel into Sweden.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210212193443/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

No change:   The Public Health Agency of Sweden recommends that adults with symptoms of COVID-19 get tested to see if they have an ongoing infection. The same recommendation applies to children of school age and older, i.e., from about 6 years of age. Younger children of preschool age are primarily advised to stay at home if they are ill, without taking a test. It is the regions that decide which people to test, and there may be regional variations from the national recommendations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212195526/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/

No change:   The treating physician or other health care personnel with special competence perform the infection tracking. The person with covid-19 is contacted and has to answer questions about who they have met and where they have been since the first signs of symptoms and 48 hours before. ... In the next step, contact is made with those who may have been exposed to infection. This is done either by the infected person himself, in dialogue with an infection tracker, or by an infection tracker in the responsible region. Anyone who is contacted in an infection tracker receives information about what this means and what measures may need to be taken.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210226205613/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/testning-och-smittsparning/smittsparning/

In the region of Västra Götaland, from 17 February, disposable masks have to be worn on public transport at all times, not just during rush hours, as well as in situations where close contact, e.g. for extended periods of time in an indoor environment, is unavoidable.    Although this is still a mere recommendation, it is a much stronger one than the mask recommendation elsewhere in the country (limited to rush hours on public transport), so I have coded it as 2T to reflect the policy change as a result of which in practice, in this region, people will be wearing masks much more often than before.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210217212115/https://www.vgregion.se/aktuellt/nyhetslista/nya-regionala-rekommendationer-i-vastra-gotaland/

Several more regions have introduced more extensive mask recommendations: the use of masks on public transport at all times, not only during rush hours, and when there is prolonged (15+ min) close contact with other people indoors. This concerns the following regions: Gävleborg, Halland, Stockholm, Sörmland, Uppsala, Västerbotten, Västra Götaland.     Although these are still mere recommendation, they are much stronger than the federal government's mask recommendation which is limited to rush hours on public transport, so I have coded it as 2T to reflect the policy change as a result of which in practice, in these regions, people will be wearing masks much more often than before.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210226195551/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/regional-information-about-coronavirus

The government continues to close its border. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "All international commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan have been cancelled and land borders are closed to passenger traffic. Some press reporting indicates that international flight restrictions are expected to continue through January 1, 2020."    "Commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan are suspended. Occasional, tightly controlled, charter flights are the only means of entering or leaving the country by air."    "As part of ongoing efforts to limit the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19), authorities in Turkmenistan have extended their suspensions of international flights until at least Jan. 31. Domestic rail and bus services also remain suspended until at least Jan. 31. All land borders with Afghanistan, Iran, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan remain closed until further notice. Only Turkmen nationals, permanent residents, diplomats, and workers in critical industries and key infrastructure are permitted to enter the country. All arrivals must undergo a 14-day quarantine in a state-run facility. While freight traffic is generally allowed to transit the border, Turkmen authorities have previously restricted cross-border freight traffic without warning or explanation. All persons departing the country must be in possession of a negative COVID-19 test certificate, signed within the previous 24 hours."    https://archive.fo/cxSs5    https://archive.vn/bUERh#selection-1611.0-1611.348    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20210128074335/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

As of 31 January, the government of Turkey has temporarily suspended flights from Brazil amid rising case numbers of a mutated variant of COVID-19.    Passengers departing from the United Kingdom will not be allowed to enter Turkey.     Only Turkish citizens, holders of Turkish residency cards and blue card holders are permitted to board flights departing from Denmark and South Africa and arriving in Turkey.     Passengers failing to submit a digital or paper copy of a negative PCR test result are not permitted to board the flights.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210131014418/https://tr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

All international passengers age 6 years and older traveling to Turkey are required to have taken a COVID-19 PCR test with a negative result within 72 hours prior to their flight. Passengers failing to submit a digital or paper copy of a negative PCR test result are not permitted to board the flight to Turkey. Passengers departing from the United Kingdom will not be allowed to enter Turkey. All passengers arriving in Turkey through third countries, who visited The United Kingdom within the last 10 days, will be quarantined for 14 days at places selected by the Turkish officials following their arrival. Passengers arriving from Denmark and South Africa should declare their residency address and stay in isolation for 7 days. PCR testing is available at Istanbul Airport. Those who are in transit, are not required to submit a PCR test in Turkey.  Link: https://archive.fo/wUcPH

All passengers aged 6 years and older traveling to Turkey are required to have taken a COVID-19 PCR test with a negative result within 72 hours prior to their flight. Passengers failing to submit a digital or paper copy of a negative PCR test result are not permitted to board the flight to Turkey. PCR testing is available at Istanbul Airport. Those who are in transit, are not required to submit a PCR test in Turkey. Passengers departing from the United Kingdom will not be allowed to enter Turkey. All passengers arriving in Turkey through third countries, who visited The United Kingdom within the last 10 days, will be quarantined for 14 days at places selected by the Turkish officials following their arrival. Passengers arriving from Denmark and South Africa should declare their residency address and stay in isolation for 7 days. Effective 22nd of January 2021, the government of Turkey has suspended flights from Brazil.  Link: https://archive.fo/NWF7w

As of 14 February, arrivals from Brazil, the United Kingdom, Denmark, and South Africa are suspended.    All passengers arriving in Turkey from other countries who visited Brazil, United Kingdom, Denmark, and South Africa (including in transit) within the last 10 days will be quarantined for 14 days at places selected by local Turkish authorities on arrival. On the 10th day of the quarantine period, passengers are required to undergo a PCR test and if the test result is negative, the isolation period will end.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214212732/https://tr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

All passengers aged 6 years and older traveling to Turkey are required to have taken a COVID-19 PCR test with a negative result within 72 hours prior to their flight. On 9 February, the wage support payments for January were distributed.   Under the allowance, the government has paid 60% of staff salaries across the country.    Coded as 0 because the deadline for new applications was 31 December 2020.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210215231828/https://ailevecalisma.gov.tr/tr-tr/haberler/bakan-selcuk-ocak-ayina-iliskin-nakdi-ucret-destegi-odemelerini-9-subat-ta-yapacagiz/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215233503/https://www.dailysabah.com/business/economy/turkey-extends-layoff-ban-by-2-more-months

On 4 February, the decision to postpone the loan debts of tradesmen and craftsmen to Halkbank was published in the Official Gazette.    The measure is effective from 1 January 2021 until 30 June 2021.    Coded as 0 because the measure is not targeted at households.     During the postponement period, the portion of the installment / principal debt and the interest to be accrued on the tradesmen and craftsmen in accordance with the relevant decisions, and the bank and insurance transactions tax related to this amount will be added equally to the remaining installments.    Within the scope of the decision, a letter of undertaking will be taken from the tradesmen and craftsmen whose loans are postponed , stating that they will not reduce the number of employees during the postponement period. Tradesmen and craftsmen with a decrease in the number of employees will be excluded from the scope of postponement.    Tradesmen and craftsmen, whose debts are deferred, may be granted a low-interest loan by the Bank within the scope of the relevant decisions regarding the provision of low-interest loans upon their request, and the provisions preventing the opening of loans to those who have debts subject to deferral will not be applied in such decisions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214091401/https://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/eskiler/2021/02/20210204-10.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210216005501/https://www.aa.com.tr/tr/ekonomi/esnaf-ve-sanatkarlarin-kredi-borclarina-erteleme/2133337

A,C:    On 28 January, vaccination efforts were expanded to people at the age of 75 and above.    People are receiving CoronaVac, developed by China’s Sinovac, an inactive vaccine the country started receiving shipments of last month.    Health care workers were the first to receive the shots, and under a mass vaccination plan, the elderly citizens are next in line. The age limit will gradually drop in line with the plan.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210201020353/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/coronavirus-vaccination-in-turkey-begins-for-citizens-75-and-above/news

On 28th of January, the vaccination of the citizens at the age of 75 and above was started with Chinese Sinovac vaccine from CoronoVac firm.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201020353/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/coronavirus-vaccination-in-turkey-begins-for-citizens-75-and-above/news

On 28th of January, the vaccination of the citizens at the age of 75 and above was started with Chinese Sinovac vaccine from CoronoVac firm.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201020353/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/coronavirus-vaccination-in-turkey-begins-for-citizens-75-and-above/news

A,C:     On 11 February, health care workers, who were first to receive jabs last month, started receiving the second dose of CoronaVac. The inactive vaccine developed by China’s Sinovac is the only one available in the country, which plans to receive its first doses of the messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine developed by Pfizer-BioNTech later this month.    While health care workers received their second jabs, people at the age of 70 and above are being administered their first shots.     The country's oldest citizens were vaccinated with their first jabs shortly after the first doses were administered to health care workers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214044314/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/2nd-shot-at-hope-turkey-starts-new-round-of-covid-19-vaccines/news

A,C:    On 12 February, people at the age of 65 or above will receive their first shots.    After completing the vaccination of senior citizens, the country will move to age-independent vaccination in the next phase of the plan. These people include soldiers, police officers, teachers and people working in sectors critical for daily life, from logistics to the food sector.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214044314/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/2nd-shot-at-hope-turkey-starts-new-round-of-covid-19-vaccines/news

A,C:    During 13-14 February, inoculation is planned for members of the Cabinet, in a bid to set an example for the public. Vaccine skeptics and anti-vaxxers thrive on social media, looking to deter inoculation, though surveys show a large majority of people are willing to be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214044314/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/2nd-shot-at-hope-turkey-starts-new-round-of-covid-19-vaccines/news

On 28th of January, the vaccination of the citizens at the age of 75 and above was started with Chinese Sinovac vaccine from CoronoVac firm.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201020353/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/coronavirus-vaccination-in-turkey-begins-for-citizens-75-and-above/news

At midnight on January 25, the intensified quarantine restrictions, which lasted from January 8, ceased to apply in Ukraine. From now and till February 28 inclusive, the country returned to the anti-epidemic rules in force in December 2020. Returning to adaptive quarantine may be considered based on the epidemiological situation.   What is prohibited:   - Visiting educational institutions by groups of more than 20 people, except for preschool, general secondary, out-of-school and specialized art education institutions.   - Visiting educational institutions when more than 50% of students and staff of the educational institution are in self-isolation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210201235758/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni  (link corrected on 16 February 2021)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125213141/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/operativna-informacija-pro-poshirennja-koronavirusnoi-infekcii-2019-cov19

No policy changes, adaptive quarantine measures are in place until 28 February.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207005538/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/timeline?type=posts  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207003902/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Current quarantine measures are in place till February 28.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207003902/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210201235758/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni

The quarantine in Ukraine has been extended until 30 April.    On 17 February, the Prime Minister of Ukraine announced that the adaptive quarantine model, which envisages setting various quarantine restrictions across regions depending on the epidemic situation therein, will return on 24 February. The Minister of Health conveyed the resolution stipulates for the establishment of a basic yellow level for the whole country. As in the summer, four levels (Red, Orange, Yellow, Green) of epidemiological danger are envisaged, each of which has clear limitations and criteria for determining:  Yellow: The yellow level is basic for the whole country and provides for appropriate restrictions and anti-epidemic measures, but with certain mitigations. Including:  Mass events (cultural, sports, etc.) will be allowed if one person is provided with 4 square meters of area, or with a full hall of more than 50% of seats. From February 26, a red level of epidemic danger will be introduced in Ivano-Frankivsk region while restrictive measures will be intensified. At the red level, it is envisaged to introduce strict quarantine restrictions that were in force during the January lockdown. Including:  The activities of catering establishments will be prohibited (except for targeted delivery and takeaway service);  The work of shopping malls and other entertainment establishments – cinemas, theaters, etc. is prohibited.  Educational institutions will not work (except kindergartens and elementary schools);  Non-food markets and shops, gyms, swimming pools and fitness centers will be closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227181512/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/premyer-ministr-rishennya-komisiyi-teb-ta-ns-maye-ne-dopustiti-podalshogo-poshirennya-covid-19-v-ivano-frankivskij-oblasti  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227182431/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/tag/ohorona-zdorovya  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227180512/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

At midnight on January 25, the intensified quarantine restrictions, which lasted from January 8, ceased to apply in Ukraine. From now and till February 28 inclusive, the country returned to the anti-epidemic rules in force in December 2020. Returning to adaptive quarantine may be considered based on the epidemiological situation.  What is prohibited:   - The work of business entities in which employees are not provided with masks, no marking on the distance between customers of 1.5 m, and visitors do not have properly worn personal protective equipment.   - The work of catering establishments from 23:00 to 7:00 (except for delivery and takeaway orders). Settlement operations are terminated after 22:00.   - Activities of accommodation establishments (except for hotels, rehabilitation centers for people with disabilities, sanatoriums).   - The work of gyms and fitness centers, if they have more than one person per 20 square meters.   - Carrying out of discos, work of night clubs and public catering establishments with the organization of leisure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210201235758/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni  (link corrected on 16 February 2021)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125213141/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/operativna-informacija-pro-poshirennja-koronavirusnoi-infekcii-2019-cov19

No policy changes, adaptive quarantine measures are in place until 28 February.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207005538/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/timeline?type=posts  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207003902/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Current quarantine measures are in place till February 28.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207003902/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201235758/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni

The quarantine in Ukraine has been extended until 30 April.    On 17 February, the Prime Minister of Ukraine announced that the adaptive quarantine model, which envisages setting various quarantine restrictions across regions depending on the epidemic situation therein, will return on 24 February. The Minister of Health conveyed the resolution stipulates for the establishment of a basic yellow level for the whole country. As in the summer, four levels (Red, Orange, Yellow, Green) of epidemiological danger are envisaged, each of which has clear limitations and criteria for determining:  Yellow: The yellow level is basic for the whole country and provides for appropriate restrictions and anti-epidemic measures, but with certain mitigations. Including:  Mass events (cultural, sports, etc.) will be allowed if one person is provided with 4 square meters of area, or with a full hall of more than 50% of seats. (Previously, there were restrictions that no more than 20 people could participate in the events and 5 square meters of area should be provided for each);  It will be allowed to visit educational institutions in groups of more than 20 people;  It will be possible to hold matches of team gaming sports, but provided that the spectators will be half of the provided seats;  Restaurants, cafes, bars and canteens will work – up to 24 hours (previously worked up to 23 hours);  Swimming pools, gyms and fitness centres are available for more people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227184208/https://covid19.gov.ua/karantynni-zakhody  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227183534/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/z-24-ljutogo-v-ukraini-zaprovadjat-adaptivnij-karantin-peredbachene-pom%e2%80%99jakshennja-obmezhen  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227180834/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/denis-shmigal-ukrayina-z-nastupnogo-tizhnya-povertayetsya-do-adaptivnogo-karantinu  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227182431/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/tag/ohorona-zdorovya  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227180512/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From February 26, a red level of epidemic danger will be introduced in Ivano-Frankivsk region while restrictive measures will be intensified. At the red level, it is envisaged to introduce strict quarantine restrictions that were in force during the January lockdown. Including:  The activities of catering establishments will be prohibited (except for targeted delivery and takeaway service);  The work of shopping malls and other entertainment establishments – cinemas, theaters, etc. is prohibited.  Educational institutions will not work (except kindergartens and elementary schools);  Non-food markets and shops, gyms, swimming pools and fitness centers will be closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227181512/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/premyer-ministr-rishennya-komisiyi-teb-ta-ns-maye-ne-dopustiti-podalshogo-poshirennya-covid-19-v-ivano-frankivskij-oblasti  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227182431/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/tag/ohorona-zdorovya  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227180512/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

At midnight on January 25, the intensified quarantine restrictions, which lasted from January 8, ceased to apply in Ukraine. From now and till February 28 inclusive, the country returned to the anti-epidemic rules in force in December 2020. Returning to adaptive quarantine may be considered based on the epidemiological situation.   What is prohibited:   - Carrying out mass events (performances, holidays, concerts) in educational institutions with the participation of children from more than one group / class and in the presence of visitors.   - Carrying out mass cultural (including concerts), sports, social, advertising and other events in which more than 20 people take part and the distance of 1.5 m between the participants is not observed (exception - official and professional sports events without spectators, notary exams and events necessary to ensure the work of the authorities).   - Carrying out in entertaining establishments and public catering establishments of celebratory actions, banquets, master classes, public events.   - Operation of cinemas and cultural institutions with more than 50% of seats in one hall. - Reception of visitors in museums, exhibitions, galleries, there is more than one person per 10 square meters.   - Religious events: indoors - subject to the presence of more than one person per 5 square meters. m; in the open air - provided that the distance of 1.5 m between those present is not observed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210201235758/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni  (link corrected on 16 February 2021)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125213141/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/operativna-informacija-pro-poshirennja-koronavirusnoi-infekcii-2019-cov19

No policy changes, adaptive quarantine measures are in place until 28 February.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207005538/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/timeline?type=posts  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207003902/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Current quarantine measures are in place till February 28.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207003902/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201235758/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni

The quarantine in Ukraine has been extended until 30 April.    On 17 February, the Prime Minister of Ukraine announced that the adaptive quarantine model, which envisages setting various quarantine restrictions across regions depending on the epidemic situation therein, will return on 24 February. The Minister of Health conveyed the resolution stipulates for the establishment of a basic yellow level for the whole country. As in the summer, four levels (Red, Orange, Yellow, Green) of epidemiological danger are envisaged, each of which has clear limitations and criteria for determining:  Yellow: The yellow level is basic for the whole country and provides for appropriate restrictions and anti-epidemic measures, but with certain mitigations. Including:  Mass events (cultural, sports, etc.) will be allowed if one person is provided with 4 square meters of area, or with a full hall of more than 50% of seats. (Previously, there were restrictions that no more than 20 people could participate in the events and 5 square meters of area should be provided for each);  It will be allowed to visit educational institutions in groups of more than 20 people;  It will be possible to hold matches of team gaming sports, but provided that the spectators will be half of the provided seats;  Restaurants, cafes, bars and canteens will work – up to 24 hours (previously worked up to 23 hours);  Swimming pools, gyms and fitness centres are available for more people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227184208/https://covid19.gov.ua/karantynni-zakhody  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227183534/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/z-24-ljutogo-v-ukraini-zaprovadjat-adaptivnij-karantin-peredbachene-pom%e2%80%99jakshennja-obmezhen  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227180834/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/denis-shmigal-ukrayina-z-nastupnogo-tizhnya-povertayetsya-do-adaptivnogo-karantinu  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227182431/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/tag/ohorona-zdorovya  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227180512/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From February 26, a red level of epidemic danger will be introduced in Ivano-Frankivsk region while restrictive measures will be intensified. At the red level, it is envisaged to introduce strict quarantine restrictions that were in force during the January lockdown. Including:  The activities of catering establishments will be prohibited (except for targeted delivery and takeaway service);  The work of shopping malls and other entertainment establishments – cinemas, theaters, etc. is prohibited.  Educational institutions will not work (except kindergartens and elementary schools);  Non-food markets and shops, gyms, swimming pools and fitness centers will be closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227181512/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/premyer-ministr-rishennya-komisiyi-teb-ta-ns-maye-ne-dopustiti-podalshogo-poshirennya-covid-19-v-ivano-frankivskij-oblasti  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227182431/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/tag/ohorona-zdorovya  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227180512/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

On 02 February, the Ministry of Finance presented a detailed analysis of the use of the COVID Response Fund in 2020 by the main budget institutions. In 2020, the amount of funds allocated from the COVID-19 Response Fund made up UAH 78.4 billion out of UAH 80.9 billion. In particular, from the general fund there was used UAH 63.7 billion out of the allocated UAH 72 billion, the special fund - UAH 2.8 billion out of the allocated UAH 6.4 billion.  The Ministry of Economic Development, Trade and Agriculture used UAH 8.8 billion out of UAH 10.7 billion, or 82.1%.  The funds were used to pay unemployment benefits, for one-time compensation to business entities for the payment of a single contribution as the obligatory state social insurance, for the payment of one-time pecuniary aid to business entities.    The Ministry of Social Policy used UAH 4 billion out of UAH 6.8 billion or 59.8% under the general fund and UAH 2.8 billion out of UAH 5.0 billion or 55.5% under the special fund.  The funds are used to provide insurance benefits for temporary incapacity, to make payments to family members of physicians who died due to COVID-19, to provide assistance to children of self-employed persons, to provide one-time financial assistance to insured persons in case of loss of income if their area of activity was completely prohibited during the quarantine restrictions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207004150/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/minfin-predstavlyaye-detalnij-analiz-vikoristannya-koshtiv-fondu-borotbi-z-covid-u-2020-roci-golovnimi-rozporyadnikami

On 26 January, the Prime Minister reminded that the National Vaccination Plan envisages 5 stages, in particular, vaccination of medical workers, the military, people in nursing homes, social workers, teachers, etc. The overall goal of the plan, according to Denys Shmyhal, is to cover at least 50% of the population by the end of 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207004635/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/premyer-ministr-ukrayina-bude-zabezpechena-neobhidnoyu-kilkistyu-efektivnih-vakcin

On 03 February, the Prime Minister announced the process of immunization of Ukrainians with the COVID-19 vaccine will begin in February and in the coming weeks, Ukraine will receive Pfizer/BioNTech vaccines.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210207004346/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/premyer-ministr-rozpoviv-podrobici-procesu-vakcinaciyi-v-ukrayini

On 05 February, the Ministry of Health received confirmation of the supply of 12 million doses of vaccines for the prevention of Covid-19 manufactured by AstraZeneca and NovaVax. Delivery will take place starting from February 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207005456/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-otrimae-sche-12-mln-doz-vakcin-vid-covid-19

The Ministry of Health plans to start a COVID-19 vaccination campaign in February 2021. The ministry plans to vaccinate 50% of the population of Ukraine in 2021-2022.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210216075614/https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-economy/3189779-ukraine-to-receive-eur-50m-from-eib-for-covid19-vaccines.html

On 22 February, the Ministry of Health of Ukraine registered a vaccine against COVID-19 Oxford/AstraZeneca for emergency use. Ukraine received information from COVAX on the supply of 2.2 to 3.7 million doses of Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccines in the first and second quarters of 2021. Ukraine has also entered into additional direct contracts for the supply of the COVID-19 vaccine, which were developed with the participation of AstraZeneca (Britain-Sweden) and NovaVax (USA) and are manufactured at the Serum Institute (India).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227182131/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/v-ukrayini-zareyestruvali-vakcinu-oxfordastrazeneca-covishield-proti-covid-19

A:     On 25 February, vaccinations in Ukraine began with the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine.  Over the two days since the start of the vaccination campaign in Ukraine, 1,338 people have been vaccinated against COVID-19. These are doctors working with coronavirus patients and the military in the area of Joint Forces Operation (JFO).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210227182640/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/viktor-lyashko-rozpoviv-pro-vakcinaciyu-proti-covid-19-v-oblastyah

The ban on flights from Great Britain, Italy, Germany, Denmark, Austria, Australia, the Netherlands, and South Africa extended until 1 March. It should be noted that the government of Uzbekistan suspended flights with the abovementioned countries on 21 December 2020. However, on 11 February it was reported that Uzbekistan resumed flights to Germany.   Links: https://archive.vn/ywfby https://archive.vn/VC2Hx

Support measures. The government reacted quickly and in proportion to the shock experienced by the economy. An Anti-Crisis Fund of UZS 10 trn sum (EUR 950 m or 1.5% of GDP) was created to cover immediate social needs and to support businesses and employment. Since February, a total of about 2.5% of GDP has been spent, accounting for a cumulative increase in social payments of 17% and of minimum wages by 10% (OECD, 2020[19]).    OECD Web Archived Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210206004922/http://www.oecd.org/coronavirus/policy-responses/covid-19-crisis-response-in-central-asia-5305f172/
No changes found

On 21 January, the law "On employment of the population" came into force. Accordingly, citizens who lost their jobs in the past 12 months are paid unemployment benefits in the amount of 50 percent of the average monthly wage.   Links: https://archive.vn/AOl4u https://archive.vn/0rGtQ

During the summer, additional support measures were developed, mainly extending measures developed under the initial package and expanding unconditional income support measures for households. According to official data to July, UZS 2.3 trn of tax incentives were provided to economic sectors, and by the end of August, USD 6.1 bn had been spent, mostly to support businesses and household incomes through the Anti-Crisis Fund.    OECD Web Archived Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210206004922/http://www.oecd.org/coronavirus/policy-responses/covid-19-crisis-response-in-central-asia-5305f172/

Currently, there is no debt relief policy for a private household. However, the government intends to extend some exemptions and benefits for about 20 thousand businesses in the field of transport, tourism, and catering until the end of 2021.   Link: https://archive.vn/iURBY https://archive.vn/DWk6z https://archive.vn/CTF5S

According to data collected by the Ministry of Public Education, from October to December, a total of 270 information sessions were conducted based on the UNFPA-developed teachers’ manual on healthy lifestyle, sexual and reproductive health, and COVID-19 prevention in Samarkand region, Tashkent Region and Karakalpakstan. The sessions reached a total of  8365 persons.  • UNICEF, the MoH and the National Agency for Electronic Mass Media (NAEMM) produced and broadcast a talk-show on mental health during COVID-19. The programme focused on pre-school children, adolescents and parents.  • UNICEF, the MoH and NAEMM produced and broadcast a TV programme on pre-school reopening during COVID-19. The programme highlighted the importance ensuring a safe school environment, provided information on measures taken to reduce infection and spread of COVID-19 at school facilities, and highlighted the importance of hygiene and physical distancing.      Web archived link:  http://archive.today/2021.02.09-150100/https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/COVID19%2520SitRep%2520Uzbekistan%252028-01-2021_Final.pdf

The Government updates the website https://coronavirus.uz/ru on a regular basis to inform the public. Moreover, 1003 is the hotline for medical questions related to COVID-19, with the information provided in Russian and Uzbek. The Government of Uzbekistan has also established an official Telegram channel for information on COVID-19 related measures. The channel can be found at https://t.me/koronavirusinfouz. Efforts to improve testing capacity, isolation measures, treatment and contact tracing were being scaled up as part of a solid, whole-of-government approach. The country had set up designated COVID-19 triage and treatment centres, and organized hospital structures and administrative systems for patient care. Intention to prioritise vaccinating medical workers and the elderly announced on the 20th Jan 2021. However, criteria to code a non-zero value not met, nil further information found to indicate the program has commenced.    Web archived link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210209170453/https://akipress.com/news:653526:Uzbekistan_to_vaccinate_medical_workers_and_elderly_people_against_coronavirus_first/

The government announced that mass vaccination will start in March, and by the end of 2021 about 7 million people, or 20% of the population, will be vaccinated. Also, the government announced that Russia's vaccine Sputnik V was certified in Uzbekistan. First of all, elderly people and medical personnel who are in contact with patients will be vaccinated. The country has already created a special working group on vaccination.   Links: https://archive.vn/aYeNA https://archive.vn/wLTWA
